column2: constructive algorithms" "Egor wants to achieve a rating of 1600 points on the well-known chess portal ChessForces and he needs your help!Before you start solving the problem
column3: Egor wants to remind you how the chess pieces move. Chess rook moves along straight lines up and down
column4: left and right
column5: as many squares as it wants. And when it wants
column6: it can stop. The queen walks in all directions vertically and diagonally at any distance. You can see the examples below.  To reach the goal
column7: Egor should research the next topic:There is an N\xc3\x97N board. Each cell of the board has a number from 1 to N2 in it and numbers in all cells are distinct.In the beginning
column8: some chess figure stands in the cell with the number 1. Note that this cell is already considered as visited. After that every move is determined by the following rules:   Among all not visited yet cells to which the figure can get in one move
column9: it goes to the cell that has minimal number. If all accessible cells were already visited and some cells are not yet visited
column10: then the figure is teleported to the not visited cell that has minimal number. If this step happens
column11: the piece pays a fee of 1 vun. If all cells are already visited
column12: the process is stopped. Egor should find an N\xc3\x97N board on which the rook pays strictly less vuns than the queen during the round with this numbering. Help him to find such N\xc3\x97N numbered board
column13: or tell that it doesn\'t exist." 2400

column3: greedy" "The King of Berland Polycarp LXXXIV has n daughters. To establish his power to the neighbouring kingdoms he wants to marry his daughters to the princes of these kingdoms. As a lucky coincidence there are n other kingdoms as well.So Polycarp LXXXIV has enumerated his daughters from 1 to n and the kingdoms from 1 to n. For each daughter he has compiled a list of kingdoms princes of which she wanted to marry.Polycarp LXXXIV is very busy
column4: so he finds a couple for his daughters greedily one after another.For the first daughter he takes the kingdom with the lowest number from her list and marries the daughter to their prince. For the second daughter he takes the kingdom with the lowest number from her list
column5: prince of which hasn\'t been taken already. If there are no free princes in the list then the daughter marries nobody and Polycarp LXXXIV proceeds to the next daughter. The process ends after the n-th daughter.For example
column6: let there be 4 daughters and kingdoms
column7: the lists daughters have are [2
column14: respectively.  In that case daughter 1 marries the prince of kingdom 2
column15: daughter 2 marries the prince of kingdom 1
column16: daughter 3 marries the prince of kingdom 3
column17: leaving daughter 4 nobody to marry to.Actually
column18: before starting the marriage process Polycarp LXXXIV has the time to convince one of his daughters that some prince is also worth marrying to. Effectively
column19: that means that he can add exactly one kingdom to exactly one of his daughter\'s list. Note that this kingdom should not be present in the daughter\'s list.Polycarp LXXXIV wants to increase the number of married couples.Unfortunately
column20: what he doesn\'t have the time for is determining what entry to add. If there is no way to increase the total number of married couples then output that the marriages are already optimal. Otherwise
column21: find such an entry that the total number of married couples increases if Polycarp LXXXIV adds it.If there are multiple ways to add an entry so that the total number of married couples increases then print any of them.For your and our convenience you are asked to answer t independent test cases." 1200

column1: 1322E "Median Mountain Range" "data structures" "Berland \xe2\x80\x94 is a huge country with diverse geography. One of the most famous natural attractions of Berland is the ""Median mountain range"". This mountain range is n mountain peaks
column2: located on one straight line and numbered in order of 1 to n. The height of the i-th mountain top is ai. ""Median mountain range"" is famous for the so called alignment of mountain peaks happening to it every day. At the moment of alignment simultaneously for each mountain from 2 to n\xe2\x88\x921 its height becomes equal to the median height among it and two neighboring mountains. Formally
column3: if before the alignment the heights were equal bi
column4: then after the alignment new heights ai are as follows: a1=b1
column5: an=bn and for all i from 2 to n\xe2\x88\x921 ai=median(bi\xe2\x88\x921
column6: bi
column7: bi+1). The median of three integers is the second largest number among them. For example
column8: median(5
column11: and median(4
column13: 4)=4.Recently
column14: Berland scientists have proved that whatever are the current heights of the mountains
column15: the alignment process will stabilize sooner or later
column16: i.e. at some point the altitude of the mountains won\'t changing after the alignment any more. The government of Berland wants to understand how soon it will happen
column17: i.e. to find the value of c \xe2\x80\x94 how many alignments will occur
column18: which will change the height of at least one mountain. Also
column19: the government of Berland needs to determine the heights of the mountains after c alignments
column20: that is
column21: find out what heights of the mountains stay forever. Help scientists solve this important problem!" 3300

column2: dp "A popular reality show is recruiting a new cast for the third season! n candidates numbered from 1 to n have been interviewed. The candidate i has aggressiveness level li
column3: and recruiting this candidate will cost the show si roubles.The show host reviewes applications of all candidates from i=1 to i=n by increasing of their indices
column4: and for each of them she decides whether to recruit this candidate or not. If aggressiveness level of the candidate i is strictly higher than that of any already accepted candidates
column5: then the candidate i will definitely be rejected. Otherwise the host may accept or reject this candidate at her own discretion. The host wants to choose the cast so that to maximize the total profit.The show makes revenue as follows. For each aggressiveness level v a corresponding profitability value cv is specified
column6: which can be positive as well as negative. All recruited participants enter the stage one by one by increasing of their indices. When the participant i enters the stage
column7: events proceed as follows:  The show makes cli roubles
column8: where li is initial aggressiveness level of the participant i.  If there are two participants with the same aggressiveness level on stage
column9: they immediately start a fight. The outcome of this is:  the defeated participant is hospitalized and leaves the show.  aggressiveness level of the victorious participant is increased by one
column10: and the show makes ct roubles
column11: where t is the new aggressiveness level.  The fights continue until all participants on stage have distinct aggressiveness levels. It is allowed to select an empty set of participants (to choose neither of the candidates).The host wants to recruit the cast so that the total profit is maximized. The profit is calculated as the total revenue from the events on stage
column12: less the total expenses to recruit all accepted participants (that is
column13: their total si). Help the host to make the show as profitable as possible." 2800

column1: 1322A "Unusual Competitions" greedy "A bracketed sequence is called correct (regular) if by inserting ""+"" and ""1"" you can get a well-formed mathematical expression from it. For example
column3: ""()"" and ""(()(()))"" are correct
column4: while "")(""
column5: ""(()"" and ""(()))("" are not.The teacher gave Dmitry\'s class a very strange task \xe2\x80\x94 she asked every student to come up with a sequence of arbitrary length
column6: consisting only of opening and closing brackets. After that all the students took turns naming the sequences they had invented. When Dima\'s turn came
column7: he suddenly realized that all his classmates got the correct bracketed sequence
column8: and whether he got the correct bracketed sequence
column9: he did not know.Dima suspects now that he simply missed the word ""correct"" in the task statement
column10: so now he wants to save the situation by modifying his sequence slightly. More precisely
column11: he can the arbitrary number of times (possibly zero) perform the reorder operation.The reorder operation consists of choosing an arbitrary consecutive subsegment (substring) of the sequence and then reordering all the characters in it in an arbitrary way. Such operation takes l nanoseconds
column12: where l is the length of the subsegment being reordered. It\'s easy to see that reorder operation doesn\'t change the number of opening and closing brackets. For example for ""))(("" he can choose the substring "")("" and do reorder "")()("" (this operation will take 2 nanoseconds).Since Dima will soon have to answer
column13: he wants to make his sequence correct as fast as possible. Help him to do this
column14: or determine that it\'s impossible." 1300

column5: you can choose some index i and remove the i-th character of s (si) if at least one of its adjacent characters is the previous letter in the Latin alphabet for si. For example

column8: the letter a has no previous letters. Note that after each removal the length of the string decreases by one. So
column9: the index i should satisfy the condition 1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4|s| during each operation.For the character si adjacent characters are si\xe2\x88\x921 and si+1. The first and the last characters of s both have only one adjacent character (unless |s|=1).Consider the following example. Let s= bacabcab.  During the first move
column10: you can remove the first character s1= b because s2= a. Then the string becomes s= acabcab.  During the second move
column11: you can remove the fifth character s5= c because s4= b. Then the string becomes s= acabab.  During the third move
column12: you can remove the sixth character s6=\'b\' because s5= a. Then the string becomes s= acaba.  During the fourth move
column13: the only character you can remove is s4= b
column14: because s3= a (or s5= a). The string becomes s= acaa and you cannot do anything with it. Your task is to find the maximum possible number of characters you can remove if you choose the sequence of operations optimally." 1600

column10: and sj the propagation speed of the virus j. The spread of the viruses happens in turns: first virus 1 spreads
column11: followed by virus 2
column12: and so on. After virus ki spreads
column13: the process starts again from virus 1.A spread turn of virus j proceeds as follows. For each city x not infected with any virus at the start of the turn
column14: at the end of the turn it becomes infected with virus j if and only if there is such a city y that: city y was infected with virus j at the start of the turn; the path between cities x and y contains at most sj edges; all cities on the path between cities x and y (excluding y) were uninfected with any virus at the start of the turn.Once a city is infected with a virus
column15: it stays infected indefinitely and can not be infected with any other virus. The spread stops once all cities are infected.You need to process q independent scenarios. Each scenario is described by ki virus species and mi important cities. For each important city determine which the virus it will be infected by in the end." 3000

column4: Ri] range. Each spell can be used at most once. It is also known that if all spells are used

column6: so each child can eat no more than one candy
column7: while the remaining candies will be equally divided between his (or her) Mom and Dad. So it turns out that if a child would be given an even amount of candies (possibly zero)
column8: then he (or she) will be unable to eat any candies and will go sad. However
column9: the rest of the children (who received an odd number of candies) will be happy.Help Santa Claus to know the maximum number of children he can make happy by casting some of his spells." 2500

column12: and among all such construction plans choose any plan with the maximum possible total number of floors." 1900

column4: math" "Nikolay has only recently started in competitive programming
column5: but already qualified to the finals of one prestigious olympiad. There going to be n participants
column6: one of whom is Nikolay. Like any good olympiad
column7: it consists of two rounds. Tired of the traditional rules
column8: in which the participant who solved the largest number of problems wins
column9: the organizers came up with different rules.Suppose in the first round participant A took x-th place and in the second round \xe2\x80\x94 y-th place. Then the total score of the participant A is sum x+y. The overall place of the participant A is the number of participants (including A) having their total score less than or equal to the total score of A. Note
column10: that some participants may end up having a common overall place. It is also important to note
column11: that in both the first and the second round there were no two participants tying at a common place. In other words
column12: for every i from 1 to n exactly one participant took i-th place in first round and exactly one participant took i-th place in second round.Right after the end of the Olympiad
column13: Nikolay was informed that he got x-th place in first round and y-th place in the second round. Nikolay doesn\'t know the results of other participants
column14: yet he wonders what is the minimum and maximum place he can take
column15: if we consider the most favorable and unfavorable outcome for him. Please help Nikolay to find the answer to this question." 1700

column2: two pointers" "The Red Kingdom is attacked by the White King and the Black King!The Kingdom is guarded by n castles
column3: the i-th castle is defended by ai soldiers. To conquer the Red Kingdom
column4: the Kings have to eliminate all the defenders. Each day the White King launches an attack on one of the castles. Then
column5: at night
column6: the forces of the Black King attack a castle (possibly the same one). Then the White King attacks a castle
column7: then the Black King
column8: and so on. The first attack is performed by the White King.Each attack must target a castle with at least one alive defender in it. There are three types of attacks:  a mixed attack decreases the number of defenders in the targeted castle by x (or sets it to 0 if there are already less than x defenders);  an infantry attack decreases the number of defenders in the targeted castle by y (or sets it to 0 if there are already less than y defenders);  a cavalry attack decreases the number of defenders in the targeted castle by z (or sets it to 0 if there are already less than z defenders). The mixed attack can be launched at any valid target (at any castle with at least one soldier). However
column9: the infantry attack cannot be launched if the previous attack on the targeted castle had the same type
column10: no matter when and by whom it was launched. The same applies to the cavalry attack. A castle that was not attacked at all can be targeted by any type of attack.The King who launches the last attack will be glorified as the conqueror of the Red Kingdom
column11: so both Kings want to launch the last attack (and they are wise enough to find a strategy that allows them to do it no matter what are the actions of their opponent
column12: if such strategy exists). The White King is leading his first attack
column13: and you are responsible for planning it. Can you calculate the number of possible options for the first attack that allow the White King to launch the last attack? Each option for the first attack is represented by the targeted castle and the type of attack
column14: and two options are different if the targeted castles or the types of attack are different." 2500

column3: trees" "You are given two integers n and d. You need to construct a rooted binary tree consisting of n vertices with a root at the vertex 1 and the sum of depths of all vertices equals to d.A tree is a connected graph without cycles. A rooted tree has a special vertex called the root. A parent of a vertex v is the last different from v vertex on the path from the root to the vertex v. The depth of the vertex v is the length of the path from the root to the vertex v. Children of vertex v are all vertices for which v is the parent. The binary tree is such a tree that no vertex has more than 2 children.You have to answer t independent test cases." 2200

column2: number theory" "In modern cryptography much is tied to the algorithmic complexity of solving several problems. One of such problems is a discrete logarithm problem. It is formulated as follows:  Let\'s fix a finite field and two it\'s elements a and b. One need to fun such x that ax=b or detect there is no such x. It is most likely that modern mankind cannot solve the problem of discrete logarithm for a sufficiently large field size. For example
column3: for a field of residues modulo prime number
column4: primes of 1024 or 2048 bits are considered to be safe. However
column5: calculations with such large numbers can place a significant load on servers that perform cryptographic operations. For this reason
column6: instead of a simple module residue field
column7: more complex fields are often used. For such field no fast algorithms that use a field structure are known
column8: smaller fields can be used and operations can be properly optimized. Developer Nikolai does not trust the generally accepted methods
column9: so he wants to invent his own. Recently
column10: he read about a very strange field \xe2\x80\x94 nimbers
column11: and thinks it\'s a great fit for the purpose. The field of nimbers is defined on a set of integers from 0 to 22k\xe2\x88\x921 for some positive integer k . Bitwise exclusive or (\xe2\x8a\x95) operation is used as addition. One of ways to define multiplication operation (\xe2\x8a\x99) is following properties:   0\xe2\x8a\x99a=a\xe2\x8a\x990=0  1\xe2\x8a\x99a=a\xe2\x8a\x991=a  a\xe2\x8a\x99b=b\xe2\x8a\x99a  a\xe2\x8a\x99(b\xe2\x8a\x99c)=(a\xe2\x8a\x99b)\xe2\x8a\x99c  a\xe2\x8a\x99(b\xe2\x8a\x95c)=(a\xe2\x8a\x99b)\xe2\x8a\x95(a\xe2\x8a\x99c)  If a=22n for some integer n>0
column12: and b<a
column13: then a\xe2\x8a\x99b=a\xe2\x8b\x85b.  If a=22n for some integer n>0
column15: this algorithm can be described by following pseudo-code. multiply(a
column16: b) {   ans = 0   for p1 in bits(a)       // numbers of bits of a equal to one       for p2 in bits(b)   // numbers of bits of b equal to one          ans = ans xor multiply_powers_of_2(1 << p1
column17: 1 << p2)   return ans;}multiply_powers_of_2(a
column18: b) {    if (a == 1 or b == 1) return a * b    n = maximal value
column19: such 2^{2^{n}} <= max(a
column20: b)    power = 2^{2^{n}};    if (a >= power and b >= power) {        return multiply(power * 3 / 2
column21: multiply_powers_of_2(a / power
column22: b / power))    } else if (a >= power) {        return multiply_powers_of_2(a / power
column23: b) * power    } else {        return multiply_powers_of_2(a
column24: b / power) * power    }}It can be shown
column25: that this operations really forms a field. Moreover
column26: than can make sense as game theory operations
column27: but that\'s not related to problem much. With the help of appropriate caching and grouping of operations

column14: as it forms a simple string \'(())\'

column16: in such a way that no more operations can be performed on the remaining string. The resulting string does not have to be empty.Since the given string is too large
column17: Kuroni is unable to figure out how to minimize the number of operations. Can you help him do it instead?A sequence of characters a is a subsequence of a string b if a can be obtained from b by deletion of several (possibly
column18: zero or all) characters." 1200

column2: Gildong decided to take some rest in a park. He sat down on a bench
column3: and soon he found two rabbits hopping around. One of the rabbits was taller than the other.He noticed that the two rabbits were hopping towards each other. The positions of the two rabbits can be represented as integer coordinates on a horizontal line. The taller rabbit is currently on position x
column4: and the shorter rabbit is currently on position y (x<y). Every second
column5: each rabbit hops to another position. The taller rabbit hops to the positive direction by a
column6: and the shorter rabbit hops to the negative direction by b.  For example
column7: let\'s say x=0
column10: and b=3. At the 1-st second
column11: each rabbit will be at position 2 and 7. At the 2-nd second
column12: both rabbits will be at position 4.Gildong is now wondering: Will the two rabbits be at the same position at the same moment? If so
column13: how long will it take? Let\'s find a moment in time (in seconds) after which the rabbits will be at the same point." 800

column3: si2
column4: \xe2\x80\xa6

column6: p=p+si1si2\xe2\x80\xa6sik). Of course

column2: greedy "You have a bag of size n. Also you have m boxes. The size of i-th box is ai
column3: where each ai is an integer non-negative power of two.You can divide boxes into two parts of equal size. Your goal is to fill the bag completely.For example
column4: if n=10 and a=[1

column7: and then divide the box of size 16. So you can fill the bag with boxes of size 1
column8: 1 and 8.Calculate the minimum number of divisions required to fill the bag of size n." 1900

column3: implementation" "Polycarp wants to assemble his own keyboard. Layouts with multiple rows are too complicated for him \xe2\x80\x94 his keyboard will consist of only one row

column5: but he doesn\'t care). He wants to assemble a keyboard that will allow to type this password very easily. He doesn\'t like to move his fingers while typing the password
column6: so

column8: they should be adjacent on the keyboard. For example
column9: if the password is abacaba
column10: then the layout cabdefghi... is perfect
column11: since characters a and c are adjacent on the keyboard
column12: and a and b are adjacent on the keyboard. It is guaranteed that there are no two adjacent equal characters in s
column13: so
column14: for example
column15: the password cannot be password (two characters s are adjacent).Can you help Polycarp with choosing the perfect layout of the keyboard
column16: if it is possible?" 1600

column1: 1303B "National Project" math "Your company was appointed to lay new asphalt on the highway of length n. You know that every day you can either repair one unit of the highway (lay new asphalt over one unit of the highway) or skip repairing.Skipping the repair is necessary because of the climate. The climate in your region is periodical: there are g days when the weather is good and if you lay new asphalt these days it becomes high-quality pavement; after that
column2: the weather during the next b days is bad
column3: and if you lay new asphalt these days it becomes low-quality pavement; again g good days
column4: b bad days and so on.You can be sure that you start repairing at the start of a good season
column5: in other words
column6: days 1
column8: \xe2\x80\xa6
column9: g are good.You don\'t really care about the quality of the highway
column10: you just want to make sure that at least half of the highway will have high-quality pavement. For example
column11: if the n=5 then at least 3 units of the highway should have high quality; if n=4 then at least 2 units should have high quality.What is the minimum number of days is needed to finish the repair of the whole highway?" 1400

column7: nobody gains a point and you both proceed to the next monster. You have some secret technique to force your opponent to skip his turn. You can use this technique at most k times in total (for example
column8: if there are two monsters and k=4
column9: then you can use the technique 2 times on the first monster and 1 time on the second monster
column10: but not 2 times on the first monster and 3 times on the second monster).Your task is to determine the maximum number of points you can gain if you use the secret technique optimally." 1500

column3: probabilities "An online contest will soon be held on ForceCoders
column4: a large competitive programming platform. The authors have prepared n problems; and since the platform is very popular
column5: 998244351 coder from all over the world is going to solve them.For each problem
column6: the authors estimated the number of people who would solve it: for the i-th problem
column7: the number of accepted solutions will be between li and ri
column8: inclusive.The creator of ForceCoders uses different criteria to determine if the contest is good or bad. One of these criteria is the number of inversions in the problem order. An inversion is a pair of problems (x
column9: y) such that x is located earlier in the contest (x<y)
column10: but the number of accepted solutions for y is strictly greater.Obviously
column11: both the creator of ForceCoders and the authors of the contest want the contest to be good. Now they want to calculate the probability that there will be no inversions in the problem order
column12: assuming that for each problem i
column13: any integral number of accepted solutions for it (between li and ri) is equally probable
column14: and all these numbers are independent." 2700

column2: interactive "This is the easy version of the problem. You can find the hard version in the Div. 1 contest. Both versions only differ in the number of times you can ask your friend to taste coffee.This is an interactive problem.You\'re considering moving to another city
column3: where one of your friends already lives. There are n caf\xc3\xa9s in this city
column4: where n is a power of two. The i-th caf\xc3\xa9 produces a single variety of coffee ai. As you\'re a coffee-lover
column5: before deciding to move or not
column6: you want to know the number d of distinct varieties of coffees produced in this city.You don\'t know the values a1
column7: \xe2\x80\xa6
column8: an. Fortunately
column9: your friend has a memory of size k
column10: where k is a power of two.Once per day
column11: you can ask him to taste a cup of coffee produced by the caf\xc3\xa9 c
column12: and he will tell you if he tasted a similar coffee during the last k days.You can also ask him to take a medication that will reset his memory. He will forget all previous cups of coffee tasted. You can reset his memory at most 30 000 times.More formally
column13: the memory of your friend is a queue S. Doing a query on caf\xc3\xa9 c will:   Tell you if ac is in S;  Add ac at the back of S;  If |S|>k

column1: 1290E "Cartesian Tree" "data structures" "Ildar is the algorithm teacher of William and Harris. Today
column2: Ildar is teaching Cartesian Tree. However
column3: Harris is sick
column4: so Ildar is only teaching William.A cartesian tree is a rooted tree
column5: that can be constructed from a sequence of distinct integers. We build the cartesian tree as follows: If the sequence is empty
column6: return an empty tree; Let the position of the maximum element be x; Remove element on the position x from the sequence and break it into the left part and the right part (which might be empty) (not actually removing it
column7: just taking it away temporarily); Build cartesian tree for each part; Create a new vertex for the element
column8: that was on the position x which will serve as the root of the new tree. Then
column9: for the root of the left part and right part
column10: if exists
column11: will become the children for this vertex; Return the tree we have gotten.For example
column12: this is the cartesian tree for the sequence 4
column18: 1:  After teaching what the cartesian tree is
column19: Ildar has assigned homework. He starts with an empty sequence a.In the i-th round
column20: he inserts an element with value i somewhere in a. Then
column21: he asks a question: what is the sum of the sizes of the subtrees for every node in the cartesian tree for the current sequence a?Node v is in the node u subtree if and only if v=u or v is in the subtree of one of the vertex u children. The size of the subtree of node u is the number of nodes v such that v is in the subtree of u.Ildar will do n rounds in total. The homework is the sequence of answers to the n questions.The next day
column22: Ildar told Harris that he has to complete the homework as well. Harris obtained the final state of the sequence a from William. However
column23: he has no idea how to find the answers to the n questions. Help Harris!" 3300

column3: interactive" "This is the hard version of the problem. You can find the easy version in the Div. 2 contest. Both versions only differ in the number of times you can ask your friend to taste coffee.This is an interactive problem.You\'re considering moving to another city
column4: where one of your friends already lives. There are n caf\xc3\xa9s in this city
column5: where n is a power of two. The i-th caf\xc3\xa9 produces a single variety of coffee ai. As you\'re a coffee-lover
column6: before deciding to move or not
column7: you want to know the number d of distinct varieties of coffees produced in this city.You don\'t know the values a1
column8: \xe2\x80\xa6
column9: an. Fortunately
column10: your friend has a memory of size k
column11: where k is a power of two.Once per day
column12: you can ask him to taste a cup of coffee produced by the caf\xc3\xa9 c
column13: and he will tell you if he tasted a similar coffee during the last k days.You can also ask him to take a medication that will reset his memory. He will forget all previous cups of coffee tasted. You can reset his memory at most 30 000 times.More formally
column14: the memory of your friend is a queue S. Doing a query on caf\xc3\xa9 c will:   Tell you if ac is in S;  Add ac at the back of S;  If |S|>k
column15: pop the front element of S. Doing a reset request will pop all elements out of S.Your friend can taste at most 3n22k cups of coffee in total. Find the diversity d (number of distinct values in the array a).Note that asking your friend to reset his memory does not count towards the number of times you ask your friend to taste a cup of coffee.In some test cases the behavior of the interactor is adaptive. It means that the array a may be not fixed before the start of the interaction and may depend on your queries. It is guaranteed that at any moment of the interaction
column16: there is at least one array a consistent with all the answers given so far." 3000

Let\'s describe a group of students by a string of capital letters ""A"" and ""P"":   ""A"" corresponds to an angry student  ""P"" corresponds to a patient student Such string describes the row from the last to the first student.Every minute every angry student throws a snowball at the next student. Formally
column5: if an angry student corresponds to the character with index i in the string describing a group then they will throw a snowball at the student that corresponds to the character with index i+1 (students are given from the last to the first student). If the target student was not angry yet

column7: they don\'t throw a snowball since there is no one in front of them.Let\'s look at the first example test. The row initially looks like this: PPAP. Then
column8: after a minute the only single angry student will throw a snowball at the student in front of them
column9: and they also become angry: PPAA. After that
column10: no more students will become angry.Your task is to help SIS.Winter teachers to determine the last moment a student becomes angry for every group." 800

column1: 1284G Seollal graphs "It is only a few days until Seollal (Korean Lunar New Year)
column2: and Jaehyun has invited his family to his garden. There are kids among the guests. To make the gathering more fun for the kids
column3: Jaehyun is going to run a game of hide-and-seek.The garden can be represented by a n\xc3\x97m grid of unit cells. Some (possibly zero) cells are blocked by rocks
column4: and the remaining cells are free. Two cells are neighbors if they share an edge. Each cell has up to 4 neighbors: two in the horizontal direction and two in the vertical direction. Since the garden is represented as a grid
column5: we can classify the cells in the garden as either ""black"" or ""white"". The top-left cell is black
column6: and two cells which are neighbors must be different colors. Cell indices are 1-based
column7: so the top-left corner of the garden is cell (1
column8: 1).Jaehyun wants to turn his garden into a maze by placing some walls between two cells. Walls can only be placed between neighboring cells. If the wall is placed between two neighboring cells a and b
column9: then the two cells a and b are not neighboring from that point. One can walk directly between two neighboring cells if and only if there is no wall directly between them. A maze must have the following property. For each pair of free cells in the maze
column10: there must be exactly one simple path between them. A simple path between cells a and b is a sequence of free cells in which the first cell is a
column11: the last cell is b
column12: all cells are distinct
column13: and any two consecutive cells are neighbors which are not directly blocked by a wall.At first
column14: kids will gather in cell (1
column16: and start the hide-and-seek game. A kid can hide in a cell if and only if that cell is free
column17: it is not (1
column19: and has exactly one free neighbor. Jaehyun planted roses in the black cells
column20: so it\'s dangerous if the kids hide there. So Jaehyun wants to create a maze where the kids can only hide in white cells.You are given the map of the garden as input. Your task is to help Jaehyun create a maze." 3300

column3: trees" "Polycarp has decided to decorate his room because the New Year is soon. One of the main decorations that Polycarp will install is the garland he is going to solder himself.Simple garlands consisting of several lamps connected by one wire are too boring for Polycarp. He is going to solder a garland consisting of n lamps and n\xe2\x88\x921 wires. Exactly one lamp will be connected to power grid
column4: and power will be transmitted from it to other lamps by the wires. Each wire connectes exactly two lamps; one lamp is called the main lamp for this wire (the one that gets power from some other wire and transmits it to this wire)
column5: the other one is called the auxiliary lamp (the one that gets power from this wire). Obviously
column6: each lamp has at most one wire that brings power to it (and this lamp is the auxiliary lamp for this wire
column7: and the main lamp for all other wires connected directly to it).Each lamp has a brightness value associated with it
column8: the i-th lamp has brightness 2i. We define the importance of the wire as the sum of brightness values over all lamps that become disconnected from the grid if the wire is cut (and all other wires are still working).Polycarp has drawn the scheme of the garland he wants to make (the scheme depicts all n lamp and n\xe2\x88\x921 wires
column9: and the lamp that will be connected directly to the grid is marked; the wires are placed in such a way that the power can be transmitted to each lamp). After that
column10: Polycarp calculated the importance of each wire
column11: enumerated them from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921 in descending order of their importance
column12: and then wrote the index of the main lamp for each wire (in the order from the first wire to the last one).The following day Polycarp bought all required components of the garland and decided to solder it \xe2\x80\x94 but he could not find the scheme. Fortunately
column13: Polycarp found the list of indices of main lamps for all wires. Can you help him restore the original scheme?" 2200

The friend cannot give the gift to himself.For each friend the value fi is known: it is either fi=0 if the i-th friend doesn\'t know whom he wants to give the gift to or 1\xe2\x89\xa4fi\xe2\x89\xa4n if the i-th friend wants to give the gift to the friend fi.You want to fill in the unknown values (fi=0) in such a way that each friend gives exactly one gift and receives exactly one gift and there is no friend who gives the gift to himself. It is guaranteed that the initial information isn\'t contradictory.If there are several answers

column1: 1283B "Candies Division" math "Santa has n candies and he wants to gift them to k kids. He wants to divide as many candies as possible between all k kids. Santa can\'t divide one candy into parts but he is allowed to not use some candies at all.Suppose the kid who recieves the minimum number of candies has a candies and the kid who recieves the maximum number of candies has b candies. Then Santa will be satisfied
column2: if the both conditions are met at the same time:  b\xe2\x88\x92a\xe2\x89\xa41 (it means b=a or b=a+1);  the number of kids who has a+1 candies (note that a+1 not necessarily equals b) does not exceed \xe2\x8c\x8ak2\xe2\x8c\x8b (less than or equal to \xe2\x8c\x8ak2\xe2\x8c\x8b). \xe2\x8c\x8ak2\xe2\x8c\x8b is k divided by 2 and rounded down to the nearest integer. For example
column3: if k=5 then \xe2\x8c\x8ak2\xe2\x8c\x8b=\xe2\x8c\x8a52\xe2\x8c\x8b=2.Your task is to find the maximum number of candies Santa can give to kids so that he will be satisfied.You have to answer t independent test cases." 900

column3: strings" "This is an interactive problem.After completing the last level of the enchanted temple
column4: you received a powerful artifact of the 255th level. Do not rush to celebrate
column5: because this artifact has a powerful rune that can be destroyed with a single spell s
column6: which you are going to find. We define the spell as some non-empty string consisting only of the letters a and b.At any time
column7: you can cast an arbitrary non-empty spell t
column8: and the rune on the artifact will begin to resist. Resistance of the rune is the edit distance between the strings that specify the casted spell t and the rune-destroying spell s.Edit distance of two strings s and t is a value equal to the minimum number of one-character operations of replacing
column9: inserting and deleting characters in s to get t. For example
column10: the distance between ababa and aaa is 2
column11: the distance between aaa and aba is 1
column12: the distance between bbaba and abb is 3. The edit distance is 0 if and only if the strings are equal.It is also worth considering that the artifact has a resistance limit  \xe2\x80\x94 if you cast more than n+2 spells
column13: where n is the length of spell s
column14: the rune will be blocked.Thus
column15: it takes n+2 or fewer spells to destroy the rune that is on your artifact. Keep in mind that the required destructive spell s must also be counted among these n+2 spells.Note that the length n of the rune-destroying spell s is not known to you in advance. It is only known that its length n does not exceed 300." 2300

column3: two pointers" "Petya has come to the math exam and wants to solve as many problems as possible. He prepared and carefully studied the rules by which the exam passes.The exam consists of n problems that can be solved in T minutes. Thus
column4: the exam begins at time 0 and ends at time T. Petya can leave the exam at any integer time from 0 to T
column5: inclusive.All problems are divided into two types:   easy problems \xe2\x80\x94 Petya takes exactly a minutes to solve any easy problem;  hard problems \xe2\x80\x94 Petya takes exactly b minutes (b>a) to solve any hard problem. Thus
column6: if Petya starts solving an easy problem at time x
column7: then it will be solved at time x+a. Similarly
column8: if at a time x Petya starts to solve a hard problem
column9: then it will be solved at time x+b.For every problem
column10: Petya knows if it is easy or hard. Also
column11: for each problem is determined time ti (0\xe2\x89\xa4ti\xe2\x89\xa4T) at which it will become mandatory (required). If Petya leaves the exam at time s and there is such a problem i that ti\xe2\x89\xa4s and he didn\'t solve it
column12: then he will receive 0 points for the whole exam. Otherwise (i.e if he has solved all such problems for which ti\xe2\x89\xa4s) he will receive a number of points equal to the number of solved problems. Note that leaving at time s Petya can have both ""mandatory"" and ""non-mandatory"" problems solved.For example
column13: if n=2
column17: the first problem is hard and t1=3 and the second problem is easy and t2=2. Then:  if he leaves at time s=0
column18: then he will receive 0 points since he will not have time to solve any problems;  if he leaves at time s=1
column19: he will receive 0 points since he will not have time to solve any problems;  if he leaves at time s=2
column20: then he can get a 1 point by solving the problem with the number 2 (it must be solved in the range from 0 to 2);  if he leaves at time s=3
column21: then he will receive 0 points since at this moment both problems will be mandatory
column22: but he will not be able to solve both of them;  if he leaves at time s=4
column23: then he will receive 0 points since at this moment both problems will be mandatory
column24: but he will not be able to solve both of them;  if he leaves at time s=5
column25: then he can get 2 points by solving all problems. Thus
column26: the answer to this test is 2.Help Petya to determine the maximal number of points that he can receive

column1: 1281B "Azamon Web Services" greedy "Your friend Jeff Zebos has been trying to run his new online company

column5: then he\'ll be at the top of the search results and will be a millionaire.After doing some research
column6: you find out that search engines only sort their results lexicographically. If your friend could rename his products to lexicographically smaller strings than his competitor\'s
column7: then he\'ll be at the top of the rankings!To make your strategy less obvious to his competitors
column8: you decide to swap no more than two letters of the product names.Please help Jeff to find improved names for his products that are lexicographically smaller than his competitor\'s!Given the string s representing Jeff\'s product name and the string c representing his competitor\'s product name
column9: find a way to swap at most one pair of characters in s (that is
column10: find two distinct indices i and j and swap si and sj) such that the resulting new name becomes strictly lexicographically smaller than c
column11: or determine that it is impossible.Note: String a is strictly lexicographically smaller than string b if and only if one of the following holds:  a is a proper prefix of b
column12: that is

column14: |b|) such that ai<bi and aj=bj for 1\xe2\x89\xa4j<i." 1600

column8: did I say three suffixes? I meant four." 800

column3: trees "The Oak has n nesting places
column4: numbered with integers from 1 to n. Nesting place i is home to bi bees and wi wasps.Some nesting places are connected by branches. We call two nesting places adjacent if there exists a branch between them. A simple path from nesting place x to y is given by a sequence s0

column6: sp of distinct nesting places
column7: where p is a non-negative integer

column11: \xe2\x80\xa6
column12: p. The branches of The Oak are set up in such a way that for any two pairs of nesting places x and y
column13: there exists a unique simple path from x to y. Because of this
column14: biologists and computer scientists agree that The Oak is in fact
column15: a tree.A village is a nonempty set V of nesting places such that for any two x and y in V
column16: there exists a simple path from x to y whose intermediate nesting places all lie in V. A set of villages P is called a partition if each of the n nesting places is contained in exactly one of the villages in P. In other words
column17: no two villages in P share any common nesting place
column18: and altogether
column19: they contain all n nesting places.The Oak holds its annual Miss Punyverse beauty pageant. The two contestants this year are Ugly Wasp and Pretty Bee. The winner of the beauty pageant is determined by voting
column20: which we will now explain. Suppose P is a partition of the nesting places into m villages V1
column21: \xe2\x80\xa6
column22: Vm. There is a local election in each village. Each of the insects in this village vote for their favorite contestant. If there are strictly more votes for Ugly Wasp than Pretty Bee
column23: then Ugly Wasp is said to win in that village. Otherwise
column24: Pretty Bee wins. Whoever wins in the most number of villages wins.As it always goes with these pageants
column25: bees always vote for the bee (which is Pretty Bee this year) and wasps always vote for the wasp (which is Ugly Wasp this year). Unlike their general elections
column26: no one abstains from voting for Miss Punyverse as everyone takes it very seriously.Mayor Waspacito
column27: and his assistant Alexwasp
column28: wants Ugly Wasp to win. He has the power to choose how to partition The Oak into exactly m villages. If he chooses the partition optimally
column29: determine the maximum number of villages in which Ugly Wasp wins." 2500

column3: greedy
column4: trees" "Welcome! Everything is fine.You have arrived in The Medium Place
column5: the place between The Good Place and The Bad Place. You are assigned a task that will either make people happier or torture them for eternity.You have a list of k pairs of people who have arrived in a new inhabited neighborhood. You need to assign each of the 2k people into one of the 2k houses. Each person will be the resident of exactly one house
column6: and each house will have exactly one resident.Of course
column7: in the neighborhood
column8: it is possible to visit friends. There are 2k\xe2\x88\x921 roads
column9: each of which connects two houses. It takes some time to traverse a road. We will specify the amount of time it takes in the input. The neighborhood is designed in such a way that from anyone\'s house
column10: there is exactly one sequence of distinct roads you can take to any other house. In other words
column11: the graph with the houses as vertices and the roads as edges is a tree.The truth is
column12: these k pairs of people are actually soulmates. We index them from 1 to k. We denote by f(i) the amount of time it takes for the i-th pair of soulmates to go to each other\'s houses.As we have said before
column13: you will need to assign each of the 2k people into one of the 2k houses. You have two missions
column14: one from the entities in The Good Place and one from the entities of The Bad Place. Here they are:  The first mission
column15: from The Good Place
column16: is to assign the people into the houses such that the sum of f(i) over all pairs i is minimized. Let\'s define this minimized sum as G. This makes sure that soulmates can easily and efficiently visit each other;  The second mission
column17: from The Bad Place
column18: is to assign the people into the houses such that the sum of f(i) over all pairs i is maximized. Let\'s define this maximized sum as B. This makes sure that soulmates will have a difficult time to visit each other. What are the values of G and B?" 2000

column2: math "You are an all-powerful being and you have created a rectangular world. In fact
column3: your world is so bland that it could be represented by a r\xc3\x97cr\xc3\x97c grid. Each cell on the grid represents a country. Each country has a dominant religion. There are only two religions in your world. One of the religions is called Beingawesomeism
column4: who do good for the sake of being good. The other religion is called Pushingittoofarism
column5: who do murders for the sake of being bad.Oh
column6: and you are actually not really all-powerful. You just have one power
column7: which you can use infinitely many times! Your power involves missionary groups. When a missionary group of a certain country
column8: say aa
column9: passes by another country bb
column10: they change the dominant religion of country bb to the dominant religion of country aa.In particular
column11: a single use of your power is this:   You choose a horizontal 1\xc3\x97x1\xc3\x97x subgrid or a vertical x\xc3\x971x\xc3\x971 subgrid. That value of xx is up to you;  You choose a direction dd. If you chose a horizontal subgrid
column12: your choices will either be NORTH or SOUTH. If you choose a vertical subgrid
column13: your choices will either be EAST or WEST;  You choose the number ss of steps;  You command each country in the subgrid to send a missionary group that will travel ss steps towards direction dd. In each step
column14: they will visit (and in effect convert the dominant religion of) all ss countries they pass through
column15: as detailed above.  The parameters xx
column16: dd
column17: ss must be chosen in such a way that any of the missionary groups won\'t leave the grid. The following image illustrates one possible single usage of your power. Here
column18: A represents a country with dominant religion Beingawesomeism and P represents a country with dominant religion Pushingittoofarism. Here
column19: we\'ve chosen a 1\xc3\x9741\xc3\x974 subgrid
column20: the direction NORTH
column21: and s=2s=2 steps.   You are a being which believes in free will
column22: for the most part. However
column23: you just really want to stop receiving murders that are attributed to your name. Hence
column24: you decide to use your powers and try to make Beingawesomeism the dominant religion in every country.What is the minimum number of usages of your power needed to convert everyone to Beingawesomeism?With god
column25: nothing is impossible. But maybe you\'re not god? If it is impossible to make Beingawesomeism the dominant religion in all countries
column26: you must also admit your mortality and say so." 1800

column2: math "We start with a string s consisting only of the digits 1
column4: or 3. The length of s is denoted by |s|. For each i from 1 to |s|
column5: the i-th character of s is denoted by si. There is one cursor. The cursor\'s location \xe2\x84\x93 is denoted by an integer in {0
column6: \xe2\x80\xa6
column8: with the following meaning:   If \xe2\x84\x93=0
column9: then the cursor is located before the first character of s.  If \xe2\x84\x93=|s|
column10: then the cursor is located right after the last character of s.  If 0<\xe2\x84\x93<|s|
column11: then the cursor is located between s\xe2\x84\x93 and s\xe2\x84\x93+1. We denote by sleft the string to the left of the cursor and sright the string to the right of the cursor. We also have a string c
column12: which we call our clipboard
column13: which starts out as empty. There are three types of actions:  The Move action. Move the cursor one step to the right. This increments \xe2\x84\x93 once.  The Cut action. Set c\xe2\x86\x90sright
column14: then set s\xe2\x86\x90sleft.  The Paste action. Append the value of c to the end of the string s. Note that this doesn\'t modify c. The cursor initially starts at \xe2\x84\x93=0. Then
column15: we perform the following procedure:  Perform the Move action once.  Perform the Cut action once.  Perform the Paste action s\xe2\x84\x93 times.  If \xe2\x84\x93=x
column16: stop. Otherwise
column17: return to step 1. You\'re given the initial string s and the integer x. What is the length of s when the procedure stops? Since this value may be very large
column18: only find it modulo 109+7. It is guaranteed that \xe2\x84\x93\xe2\x89\xa4|s| at any time." 1700

column2: dp" "New Year is getting near. So it\'s time to change handles on codeforces. Mishka wants to change his handle but in such a way that people would not forget who he is.To make it work

column8: and upper is the number of uppercase letters) can be obtained after optimal sequence of changes?" 2800

column3: probabilities "Santa Claus has received letters from n different kids throughout this year. Of course
column4: each kid wants to get some presents from Santa: in particular
column5: the i-th kid asked Santa to give them one of ki different items as a present. Some items could have been asked by multiple kids.Santa is really busy
column6: so he wants the New Year Bot to choose the presents for all children. Unfortunately
column7: the Bot\'s algorithm of choosing presents is bugged. To choose a present for some kid
column8: the Bot does the following:  choose one kid x equiprobably among all n kids;  choose some item y equiprobably among all kx items kid x wants;  choose a kid z who will receive the present equipropably among all n kids (this choice is independent of choosing x and y); the resulting triple (x
column9: y
column10: z) is called the decision of the Bot. If kid z listed item y as an item they want to receive
column11: then the decision valid. Otherwise
column12: the Bot\'s choice is invalid.Santa is aware of the bug
column13: but he can\'t estimate if this bug is really severe. To do so
column14: he wants to know the probability that one decision generated according to the aforementioned algorithm is valid. Can you help him?" 1700

column2: implementation" "Santa has to send presents to the kids. He has a large stack of n presents
column3: numbered from 1 to n; the topmost present has number a1
column4: the next present is a2
column5: and so on; the bottom present has number an. All numbers are distinct.Santa has a list of m distinct presents he has to send: b1
column6: b2
column8: bm. He will send them in the order they appear in the list.To send a present
column9: Santa has to find it in the stack by removing all presents above it
column10: taking this present and returning all removed presents on top of the stack. So
column11: if there are k presents above the present Santa wants to send
column12: it takes him 2k+1 seconds to do it. Fortunately
column13: Santa can speed the whole process up \xe2\x80\x94 when he returns the presents to the stack
column14: he may reorder them as he wishes (only those which were above the present he wanted to take; the presents below cannot be affected in any way).What is the minimum time required to send all of the presents
column15: provided that Santa knows the whole list of presents he has to send and reorders the presents optimally? Santa cannot change the order of presents or interact with the stack of presents in any other way.Your program has to answer t different test cases." 1400

column1: 1279A "New Year Garland" math "Polycarp is sad \xe2\x80\x94 New Year is coming in few days but there is still no snow in his city. To bring himself New Year mood

column11: respectively). Note that it\'s ok to have lamps of the same color on the ends of the garland.However
column12: if you provide
column13: say
column14: 1 red
column15: 10 green and 2 blue lamps then the store workers won\'t be able to build any garland of them. Any garland consisting of these lamps will have at least one pair of lamps of the same color adjacent to each other. Note that the store workers should use all the lamps you provided.So Polycarp has bought some sets of lamps and now he wants to know if the store workers can build a garland from each of them." 900

column5: probabilities" "Consider the following experiment. You have a deck of m cards
column6: and exactly one card is a joker. n times
column7: you do the following: shuffle the deck
column8: take the top card of the deck
column9: look at it and return it into the deck.Let x be the number of times you have taken the joker out of the deck during this experiment. Assuming that every time you shuffle the deck
column10: all m! possible permutations of cards are equiprobable
column11: what is the expected value of xk? Print the answer modulo 998244353." 2600

column3: greedy
column4: implementation" "Karlsson has recently discovered a huge stock of berry jam jars in the basement of the house. More specifically
column5: there were 2n jars of strawberry and blueberry jam.All the 2n jars are arranged in a row. The stairs to the basement are exactly in the middle of that row. So when Karlsson enters the basement
column6: he sees exactly n jars to his left and n jars to his right.For example
column7: the basement might look like this:  Being the starightforward man he is
column8: he immediately starts eating the jam. In one minute he chooses to empty either the first non-empty jar to his left or the first non-empty jar to his right.Finally
column9: Karlsson decided that at the end the amount of full strawberry and blueberry jam jars should become the same.For example
column10: this might be the result:  He has eaten 1 jar to his left and then 5 jars to his right. There remained exactly 3 full jars of both strawberry and blueberry jam. Jars are numbered from 1 to 2n from left to right
column11: so Karlsson initially stands between jars n and n+1.What is the minimum number of jars Karlsson is required to empty so that an equal number of full strawberry and blueberry jam jars is left?Your program should answer t independent test cases." 1700

column2: math "You are given two integers a and b. You can perform a sequence of operations: during the first operation you choose one of these numbers and increase it by 1; during the second operation you choose one of these numbers and increase it by 2
column3: and so on. You choose the number of these operations yourself.For example
column4: if a=1 and b=3
column5: you can perform the following sequence of three operations:   add 1 to a
column6: then a=2 and b=3;  add 2 to b
column7: then a=2 and b=5;  add 3 to a
column8: then a=5 and b=5. Calculate the minimum number of operations required to make a and b equal." 1500

column3: strings" "Polycarp has built his own web service. Being a modern web service it includes login feature. And that always implies password security problems.Polycarp decided to store the hash of the password
column4: generated by the following algorithm:  take the password p
column5: consisting of lowercase Latin letters
column6: and shuffle the letters randomly in it to obtain p\xe2\x80\xb2 (p\xe2\x80\xb2 can still be equal to p);  generate two random strings
column7: consisting of lowercase Latin letters
column8: s1 and s2 (any of these strings can be empty);  the resulting hash h=s1+p\xe2\x80\xb2+s2
column9: where addition is string concatenation. For example
column10: let the password p= ""abacaba"". Then p\xe2\x80\xb2 can be equal to ""aabcaab"". Random strings s1= ""zyx"" and s2= ""kjh"". Then h= ""zyxaabcaabkjh"".Note that no letters could be deleted or added to p to obtain p\xe2\x80\xb2
column11: only the order could be changed.Now Polycarp asks you to help him to implement the password check module. Given the password p and the hash h
column12: check that h can be the hash for the password p.Your program should answer t independent test cases." 1000

column3: implementation
column4: math" "Polycarp has n different binary words. A word called binary if it contains only characters \'0\' and \'1\'. For example
column5: these words are binary: ""0001""
column7: ""0"" and ""0011100"".Polycarp wants to offer his set of n binary words to play a game ""words"". In this game
column8: players name words and each next word (starting from the second) must start with the last character of the previous word. The first word can be any. For example
column9: these sequence of words can be named during the game: ""0101""
column13: ""00001"".Word reversal is the operation of reversing the order of the characters. For example
column14: the word ""0111"" after the reversal becomes ""1110""
column15: the word ""11010"" after the reversal becomes ""01011"".Probably
column16: Polycarp has such a set of words that there is no way to put them in the order correspondent to the game rules. In this situation
column17: he wants to reverse some words from his set so that:  the final set of n words still contains different words (i.e. all words are unique);  there is a way to put all words of the final set of words in the order so that the final sequence of n words is consistent with the game rules. Polycarp wants to reverse minimal number of words. Please
column18: help him." 1900

column8: 44 and 999999. The following numbers are not beautiful: 12
column10: 6969 and 987654321.Of course
column11: Polycarpus uses the decimal numeral system (i.e. radix is 10).Help Polycarpus to find the number of numbers from 1 to n (inclusive) that are beautiful." 1000

column7: t1

column9: tn}. The empty string should be counted.Note that *\'s are just characters and do not play any special role as in
column10: for example
column11: regex matching." 3400

column1: 1276E "Four Stones" "constructive algorithms" "There are four stones on an infinite line in integer coordinates a1
column3: a3
column4: a4. The goal is to have the stones in coordinates b1
column5: b2
column6: b3
column7: b4. The order of the stones does not matter
column8: that is
column9: a stone from any position ai can end up in at any position bj
column10: provided there is a required number of stones in each position (that is
column11: if a coordinate x appears k times among numbers b1
column12: \xe2\x80\xa6
column13: b4
column14: there should be exactly k stones at x in the end).We are allowed to move stones with the following operation: choose two stones at distinct positions x and y with at least one stone each
column15: and move one stone from x to 2y\xe2\x88\x92x. In other words
column16: the operation moves a stone to a symmetric position relative to some other stone. At any moment it is allowed to have any number of stones at the same position.Find any sequence of operations that achieves the goal
column17: or determine that it is impossible. The sequence does not have to be shortest
column18: but it may contain at most 1000 operations." 3500

column2: trees "Vasya has a tree with n vertices numbered from 1 to n
column3: and n\xe2\x88\x921 edges numbered from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921. Initially each vertex contains a token with the number of the vertex written on it.Vasya plays a game. He considers all edges of the tree by increasing of their indices. For every edge he acts as follows: If both endpoints of the edge contain a token
column4: remove a token from one of the endpoints and write down its number. Otherwise
column5: do nothing.The result of the game is the sequence of numbers Vasya has written down. Note that there may be many possible resulting sequences depending on the choice of endpoints when tokens are removed.Vasya has played for such a long time that he thinks he exhausted all possible resulting sequences he can obtain. He wants you to verify him by computing the number of distinct sequences modulo 998244353." 2900

Print the rectangle itself." 2300

column1: 1276A "As Simple as One and Two" dp
column2: greedy "You are given a non-empty string s=s1s2\xe2\x80\xa6sn
column3: which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Polycarp does not like a string if it contains at least one string ""one"" or at least one string ""two"" (or both at the same time) as a substring. In other words
column4: Polycarp does not like the string s if there is an integer j (1\xe2\x89\xa4j\xe2\x89\xa4n\xe2\x88\x922)
column5: that sjsj+1sj+2=""one"" or sjsj+1sj+2=""two"".For example:  Polycarp does not like strings ""oneee""
column6: ""ontwow""
column7: ""twone"" and ""oneonetwo"" (they all have at least one substring ""one"" or ""two"")
column8: Polycarp likes strings ""oonnee""
column9: ""twwwo"" and ""twnoe"" (they have no substrings ""one"" and ""two""). Polycarp wants to select a certain set of indices (positions) and remove all letters on these positions. All removals are made at the same time.For example
column10: if the string looks like s=""onetwone""
column11: then if Polycarp selects two indices 3 and 6
column12: then ""onetwone"" will be selected and the result is ""ontwne"".What is the minimum number of indices (positions) that Polycarp needs to select to make the string liked? What should these positions be?" 1400

column3: two pointers" "You are given two bracket sequences (not necessarily regular) s and t consisting only of characters \'(\' and \')\'. You want to construct the shortest regular bracket sequence that contains both given bracket sequences as subsequences (not necessarily contiguous).Recall what is the regular bracket sequence:  () is the regular bracket sequence;  if S is the regular bracket sequence
column4: then (S) is a regular bracket sequence;  if S and T regular bracket sequences
column5: then ST (concatenation of S and T) is a regular bracket sequence. Recall that the subsequence of the string s is such string t that can be obtained from s by removing some (possibly
column6: zero) amount of characters. For example
column7: ""coder""
column8: ""force""
column9: ""cf"" and ""cores"" are subsequences of ""codeforces""
column10: but ""fed"" and ""z"" are not." 2200

column3: shortest paths" "You are given an array a consisting of n integers. In one move
column4: you can jump from the position i to the position i\xe2\x88\x92ai (if 1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x88\x92ai) or to the position i+ai (if i+ai\xe2\x89\xa4n).For each position i from 1 to n you want to know the minimum the number of moves required to reach any position j such that aj has the opposite parity from ai (i.e. if ai is odd then aj has to be even and vice versa)." 1900

column2: dp" "You are given an array a consisting of n integers.You can remove at most one element from this array. Thus
column3: the final length of the array is n\xe2\x88\x921 or n.Your task is to calculate the maximum possible length of the strictly increasing contiguous subarray of the remaining array.Recall that the contiguous subarray a with indices from l to r is a[l\xe2\x80\xa6r]=al
column4: al+1
column5: \xe2\x80\xa6
column6: ar. The subarray a[l\xe2\x80\xa6r] is called strictly increasing if al<al+1<\xe2\x8b\xaf<ar." 1500

column3: implementation "Recently
column4: Norge found a string s=s1s2\xe2\x80\xa6sn consisting of n lowercase Latin letters. As an exercise to improve his typing speed
column5: he decided to type all substrings of the string s. Yes
column6: all n(n+1)2 of them!A substring of s is a non-empty string x=s[a\xe2\x80\xa6b]=sasa+1\xe2\x80\xa6sb (1\xe2\x89\xa4a\xe2\x89\xa4b\xe2\x89\xa4n). For example
column7: ""auto"" and ""ton"" are substrings of ""automaton"".Shortly after the start of the exercise
column8: Norge realized that his keyboard was broken
column9: namely
column10: he could use only k Latin letters c1
column11: c2
column12: \xe2\x80\xa6
column13: ck out of 26.After that
column14: Norge became interested in how many substrings of the string s he could still type using his broken keyboard. Help him to find this number." 1200

column3: implementation" "Recently you have bought a snow walking robot and brought it home. Suppose your home is a cell (0
column4: 0) on an infinite grid.You also have the sequence of instructions of this robot. It is written as the string s consisting of characters \'L\'
column6: \'U\' and \'D\'. If the robot is in the cell (x
column7: y) right now
column8: he can move to one of the adjacent cells (depending on the current instruction).  If the current instruction is \'L\'
column9: then the robot can move to the left to (x\xe2\x88\x921
column10: y);  if the current instruction is \'R\'
column11: then the robot can move to the right to (x+1
column12: y);  if the current instruction is \'U\'
column13: then the robot can move to the top to (x
column14: y+1);  if the current instruction is \'D\'
column15: then the robot can move to the bottom to (x
column16: y\xe2\x88\x921). You\'ve noticed the warning on the last page of the manual: if the robot visits some cell (except (0
column17: 0)) twice then it breaks.So the sequence of instructions is valid if the robot starts in the cell (0
column19: performs the given instructions
column20: visits no cell other than (0
column21: 0) two or more times and ends the path in the cell (0
column22: 0). Also cell (0
column23: 0) should be visited at most two times: at the beginning and at the end (if the path is empty then it is visited only once). For example
column24: the following sequences of instructions are considered valid: ""UD""
column27: and the following are considered invalid: ""U"" (the endpoint is not (0
column28: 0)) and ""UUDD"" (the cell (0
column29: 1) is visited twice).The initial sequence of instructions
column31: might be not valid. You don\'t want your robot to break so you decided to reprogram it in the following way: you will remove some (possibly
column32: all or none) instructions from the initial sequence of instructions
column33: then rearrange the remaining instructions as you wish and turn on your robot to move. Your task is to remove as few instructions from the initial sequence as possible and rearrange the remaining ones so that the sequence is valid. Report the valid sequence of the maximum length you can obtain.Note that you can choose any order of remaining instructions (you don\'t need to minimize the number of swaps or any other similar metric).You have to answer q independent test cases." 1200

column3: math
column4: sortings" "Three friends are going to meet each other. Initially
column5: the first friend stays at the position x=a
column6: the second friend stays at the position x=b and the third friend stays at the position x=c on the coordinate axis Ox.In one minute each friend independently from other friends can change the position x by 1 to the left or by 1 to the right (i.e. set x:=x\xe2\x88\x921 or x:=x+1) or even don\'t change it.Let\'s introduce the total pairwise distance \xe2\x80\x94 the sum of distances between each pair of friends. Let a\xe2\x80\xb2
column7: b\xe2\x80\xb2 and c\xe2\x80\xb2 be the final positions of the first
column8: the second and the third friend
column9: correspondingly. Then the total pairwise distance is |a\xe2\x80\xb2\xe2\x88\x92b\xe2\x80\xb2|+|a\xe2\x80\xb2\xe2\x88\x92c\xe2\x80\xb2|+|b\xe2\x80\xb2\xe2\x88\x92c\xe2\x80\xb2|
column10: where |x| is the absolute value of x.Friends are interested in the minimum total pairwise distance they can reach if they will move optimally. Each friend will move no more than once. So
column11: more formally
column12: they want to know the minimum total pairwise distance they can reach after one minute.You have to answer q independent test cases." 900

column1: 1271F "Divide The Students" "brute force" "Recently a lot of students were enrolled in Berland State University. All students were divided into groups according to their education program. Some groups turned out to be too large to attend lessons in the same auditorium
column2: so these groups should be divided into two subgroups. Your task is to help divide the first-year students of the computer science faculty.There are t new groups belonging to this faculty. Students have to attend classes on three different subjects \xe2\x80\x94 maths
column3: programming and P.\xe2\x80\x89E. All classes are held in different places according to the subject \xe2\x80\x94 maths classes are held in auditoriums
column4: programming classes are held in computer labs
column5: and P. E. classes are held in gyms.Each group should be divided into two subgroups so that there is enough space in every auditorium
column6: lab or gym for all students of the subgroup. For the first subgroup of the i-th group
column7: maths classes are held in an auditorium with capacity of ai
column8: 1 students; programming classes are held in a lab that accomodates up to bi
column9: 1 students; and P.\xe2\x80\x89E. classes are held in a gym having enough place for ci
column10: 1 students. Analogically
column11: the auditorium
column12: lab and gym for the second subgroup can accept no more than ai
column14: bi
column15: 2 and ci
column16: 2 students
column17: respectively.As usual
column18: some students skip some classes. Each student considers some number of subjects (from 0 to 3) to be useless \xe2\x80\x94 that means
column19: he skips all classes on these subjects (and attends all other classes). This data is given to you as follows \xe2\x80\x94 the i-th group consists of:  di
column20: 1 students which attend all classes;  di
column21: 2 students which attend all classes
column22: except for P.\xe2\x80\x89E.;  di
column23: 3 students which attend all classes
column24: except for programming;  di
column25: 4 students which attend only maths classes;  di
column27: except for maths;  di
column28: 6 students which attend only programming classes;  di
column29: 7 students which attend only P.\xe2\x80\x89E. There is one more type of students \xe2\x80\x94 those who don\'t attend any classes at all (but they
column31: don\'t need any place in auditoriums
column32: labs or gyms
column33: so the number of those students is insignificant in this problem).Your task is to divide each group into two subgroups so that every auditorium (or lab
column34: or gym) assigned to each subgroup has enough place for all students from this subgroup attending the corresponding classes (if it is possible). Each student of the i-th group should belong to exactly one subgroup of the i-th group; it is forbidden to move students between groups." 2700

column3: greedy
column4: implementation
column5: sortings" "You play a strategic video game (yeah
column6: we ran out of good problem legends). In this game you control a large army
column7: and your goal is to conquer n castles of your opponent.Let\'s describe the game process in detail. Initially you control an army of k warriors. Your enemy controls n castles; to conquer the i-th castle
column8: you need at least ai warriors (you are so good at this game that you don\'t lose any warriors while taking over a castle
column9: so your army stays the same after the fight). After you take control over a castle
column10: you recruit new warriors into your army \xe2\x80\x94 formally
column11: after you capture the i-th castle
column12: bi warriors join your army. Furthermore
column13: after capturing a castle (or later) you can defend it: if you leave at least one warrior in a castle
column14: this castle is considered defended. Each castle has an importance parameter ci
column15: and your total score is the sum of importance values over all defended castles. There are two ways to defend a castle:  if you are currently in the castle i
column16: you may leave one warrior to defend castle i;  there are m one-way portals connecting the castles. Each portal is characterised by two numbers of castles u and v (for each portal holds u>v). A portal can be used as follows: if you are currently in the castle u
column17: you may send one warrior to defend castle v. Obviously
column18: when you order your warrior to defend some castle
column19: he leaves your army.You capture the castles in fixed order: you have to capture the first one
column20: then the second one
column21: and so on. After you capture the castle i (but only before capturing castle i+1) you may recruit new warriors from castle i
column22: leave a warrior to defend castle i
column23: and use any number of portals leading from castle i to other castles having smaller numbers. As soon as you capture the next castle
column24: these actions for castle i won\'t be available to you.If
column25: during some moment in the game
column26: you don\'t have enough warriors to capture the next castle
column27: you lose. Your goal is to maximize the sum of importance values over all defended castles (note that you may hire new warriors in the last castle
column28: defend it and use portals leading from it even after you capture it \xe2\x80\x94 your score will be calculated afterwards).Can you determine an optimal strategy of capturing and defending the castles?" 2100

column3: greedy
column4: implementation" "The map of the capital of Berland can be viewed on the infinite coordinate plane. Each point with integer coordinates contains a building
column5: and there are streets connecting every building to four neighbouring buildings. All streets are parallel to the coordinate axes.The main school of the capital is located in (sx
column6: sy). There are n students attending this school
column7: the i-th of them lives in the house located in (xi
column8: yi). It is possible that some students live in the same house
column9: but no student lives in (sx
column10: sy).After classes end
column11: each student walks from the school to his house along one of the shortest paths. So the distance the i-th student goes from the school to his house is |sx\xe2\x88\x92xi|+|sy\xe2\x88\x92yi|.The Provision Department of Berland has decided to open a shawarma tent somewhere in the capital (at some point with integer coordinates). It is considered that the i-th student will buy a shawarma if at least one of the shortest paths from the school to the i-th student\'s house goes through the point where the shawarma tent is located. It is forbidden to place the shawarma tent at the point where the school is located
column12: but the coordinates of the shawarma tent may coincide with the coordinates of the house of some student (or even multiple students).You want to find the maximum possible number of students buying shawarma and the optimal location for the tent itself." 1300

column2: math "There are n blocks arranged in a row and numbered from left to right
column3: starting from one. Each block is either black or white. You may perform the following operation zero or more times: choose two adjacent blocks and invert their colors (white block becomes black
column4: and vice versa). You want to find a sequence of operations
column5: such that they make all the blocks having the same color. You don\'t have to minimize the number of operations
column6: but it should not exceed 3\xe2\x8b\x85n. If it is impossible to find such a sequence of operations
column7: you need to report it." 1300

column3: math" "A new delivery of clothing has arrived today to the clothing store. This delivery consists of a ties
column4: b scarves
column5: c vests and d jackets.The store does not sell single clothing items \xe2\x80\x94 instead
column6: it sells suits of two types:  a suit of the first type consists of one tie and one jacket;  a suit of the second type consists of one scarf
column7: one vest and one jacket. Each suit of the first type costs e coins
column8: and each suit of the second type costs f coins.Calculate the maximum possible cost of a set of suits that can be composed from the delivered clothing items. Note that one item cannot be used in more than one suit (though some items may be left unused)." 800
