column2: math "Karl is developing a key storage service. Each user has a positive integer key.Karl knows that storing keys in plain text is bad practice. So
column3: instead of storing a key
column4: he decided to store a fingerprint of a key. However
column5: using some existing fingerprint algorithm looked too boring to him
column6: so he invented his own one.Karl\'s fingerprint is calculated by the following process: divide the given integer by 2
column7: then divide the result by 3
column8: then divide the result by 4
column9: and so on
column10: until we get a result that equals zero (we are speaking about integer division each time). The fingerprint is defined as the multiset of the remainders of these divisions. For example
column11: this is how Karl\'s fingerprint algorithm is applied to the key 11: 11 divided by 2 has remainder 1 and result 5
column12: then 5 divided by 3 has remainder 2 and result 1
column13: and 1 divided by 4 has remainder 1 and result 0. Thus
column14: the key 11 produces the sequence of remainders [1
column16: 1] and has the fingerprint multiset {1
column18: 2}.Ksenia wants to prove that Karl\'s fingerprint algorithm is not very good. For example
column19: she found that both keys 178800 and 123456 produce the fingerprint of {0
column27: users are at risk of fingerprint collision with some commonly used and easy to guess keys like 123456.Ksenia wants to make her words more persuasive. She wants to calculate the number of other keys that have the same fingerprint as the keys in the given list of some commonly used keys. Your task is to help her." 2100

column2: probabilities "Esports is a form of competitive sports using video games. Dota 2 is one of the most popular competitive video games in Esports. Recently
column3: a new video game Dota 3 was released. In Dota 3 a player can buy some relics for their hero. Relics are counters that track hero\'s actions and statistics in a game.Gloria likes to play Dota 3
column4: so she wants to buy all n available relics for her favorite hero.Relics can be bought using an in-game currency called shards. Each relic has its own price \xe2\x80\x94 ci shards for the i-th relic. A player can buy a relic using one of the following options:   Pay ci shards to buy the i-th relic;  Pay x shards and randomly get one of all n relics. The probability of getting a relic is the same for all n relics. If a duplicate relic is received
column5: then the relic is recycled and x2 shards are given back to the player. Gloria wants to buy all n relics. Help her minimize the expected number of shards she spends to buy all the relics." 3000

column1: 1267E Elections greedy "Byteburg Senate elections are coming. Usually ""United Byteland""
column3: takes all the seats in the Senate to ensure stability and sustainable development. But this year there is one opposition candidate in one of the constituencies. Even one opposition member can disturb the stability in the Senate
column4: so the head of the Party asks you to ensure that the opposition candidate will not be elected.There are n candidates
column5: numbered from 1 to n. Candidate n is the opposition candidate. There are m polling stations in the constituency
column6: numbered from 1 to m. You know the number of votes cast for each candidate at each polling station. The only thing you can do to prevent the election of the opposition candidate is to cancel the election results at some polling stations. The opposition candidate will be elected if the sum of the votes cast in their favor at all non-canceled stations will be strictly greater than the analogous sum for every other candidate. Your task is to prevent the election of the opposition candidate by canceling the election results at the minimal possible number of polling stations. Notice that solution always exists
column7: because if you cancel the elections at all polling stations
column8: the number of votes for each candidate will be 0
column9: and the opposition candidate will not be elected." 1700

column1: 1267D "DevOps Best Practices" "constructive algorithms" "Daisy is a senior software engineer at RainyDay
column2: LLC. She has just implemented three new features in their product: the first feature makes their product work
column3: the second one makes their product fast
column4: and the third one makes their product correct. The company encourages at least some testing of new features
column5: so Daisy appointed her intern Demid to write some tests for the new features.Interestingly enough
column6: these three features pass all the tests on Demid\'s development server
column7: which has index 1
column8: but might fail the tests on some other servers.After Demid has completed this task
column9: Daisy appointed you to deploy these three features to all n servers of your company. For every feature f and every server s
column10: Daisy told you whether she wants the feature f to be deployed on the server s. If she wants it to be deployed
column11: it must be done even if the feature f fails the tests on the server s. If she does not want it to be deployed
column12: you may not deploy it there.Your company has two important instruments for the deployment of new features to servers: Continuous Deployment (CD) and Continuous Testing (CT). CD can be established between several pairs of servers
column13: forming a directed graph. CT can be set up on some set of servers.If CD is configured from the server s1 to the server s2 then every time s1 receives a new feature f the system starts the following deployment process of f to s2:  If the feature f is already deployed on the server s2
column14: then nothing is done.  Otherwise
column15: if CT is not set up on the server s1
column16: then the server s1 just deploys the feature f to the server s2 without any testing.  Otherwise
column17: the server s1 runs tests for the feature f. If the tests fail on the server s1
column18: nothing is done. If the tests pass
column19: then the server s1 deploys the feature f to the server s2. You are to configure the CD/CT system
column20: and after that Demid will deploy all three features on his development server. Your CD/CT system must deploy each feature exactly to the set of servers that Daisy wants.Your company does not have a lot of computing resources
column21: so you can establish CD from one server to another at most 264 times." 2800

column3: implementation" "Bob is playing a game of Spaceship Solitaire. The goal of this game is to build a spaceship. In order to do this
column4: he first needs to accumulate enough resources for the construction. There are n types of resources
column5: numbered 1 through n. Bob needs at least ai pieces of the i-th resource to build the spaceship. The number ai is called the goal for resource i.Each resource takes 1 turn to produce and in each turn only one resource can be produced. However
column6: there are certain milestones that speed up production. Every milestone is a triple (sj
column7: tj
column8: uj)
column9: meaning that as soon as Bob has tj units of the resource sj
column10: he receives one unit of the resource uj for free
column11: without him needing to spend a turn. It is possible that getting this free resource allows Bob to claim reward for another milestone. This way
column12: he can obtain a large number of resources in a single turn.The game is constructed in such a way that there are never two milestones that have the same sj and tj
column13: that is
column14: the award for reaching tj units of resource sj is at most one additional resource.A bonus is never awarded for 0 of any resource
column15: neither for reaching the goal ai nor for going past the goal \xe2\x80\x94 formally
column16: for every milestone 0<tj<asj.A bonus for reaching certain amount of a resource can be the resource itself
column17: that is
column18: sj=uj.Initially there are no milestones. You are to process q updates

column2: probabilities "This is the hard version of this problem. The only difference is the limit of n - the length of the input string. In this version
column3: 1\xe2\x89\xa4n\xe2\x89\xa4106.Let\'s define a correct bracket sequence and its depth as follow:  An empty string is a correct bracket sequence with depth 0.  If ""s"" is a correct bracket sequence with depth d then ""(s)"" is a correct bracket sequence with depth d+1.  If ""s"" and ""t"" are both correct bracket sequences then their concatenation ""st"" is a correct bracket sequence with depth equal to the maximum depth of s and t. For a (not necessarily correct) bracket sequence s
column4: we define its depth as the maximum depth of any correct bracket sequence induced by removing some characters from s (possibly zero). For example: the bracket sequence s=""())(())"" has depth 2
column5: because by removing the third character we obtain a correct bracket sequence ""()(())"" with depth 2.Given a string a consists of only characters \'(\'
column6: \')\' and \'?\'. Consider all (not necessarily correct) bracket sequences obtained by replacing all characters \'?\' in a by either \'(\' or \')\'. Calculate the sum of all the depths of all these bracket sequences. As this number can be large
column7: find it modulo 998244353.Hacks in this problem can be done only if easy and hard versions of this problem was solved." 2900

column10: s>0 and b>0);  the number of gold medals must be strictly less than the number of silver and the number of bronze (that is

column6: trees" "An electrical grid in Berland palaces consists of 2 grids: main and reserve. Wires in palaces are made of expensive material
column7: so selling some of them would be a good idea!Each grid (main and reserve) has a head node (its number is 1). Every other node gets electricity from the head node. Each node can be reached from the head node by a unique path. Also
column8: both grids have exactly n nodes
column9: which do not spread electricity further.In other words
column10: every grid is a rooted directed tree on n leaves with a root in the node
column11: which number is 1. Each tree has independent enumeration and nodes from one grid are not connected with nodes of another grid.Also
column12: the palace has n electrical devices. Each device is connected with one node of the main grid and with one node of the reserve grid. Devices connect only with nodes
column13: from which electricity is not spread further (these nodes are the tree\'s leaves). Each grid\'s leaf is connected with exactly one device.  In this example the main grid contains 6 nodes (the top tree) and the reserve grid contains 4 nodes (the lower tree). There are 3 devices with numbers colored in blue. It is guaranteed that the whole grid (two grids and n devices) can be shown in this way (like in the picture above):  main grid is a top tree
column14: whose wires are directed \'from the top to the down\'
column15: reserve grid is a lower tree
column16: whose wires are directed \'from the down to the top\'
column17: devices \xe2\x80\x94 horizontal row between two grids
column18: which are numbered from 1 to n from the left to the right
column19: wires between nodes do not intersect. Formally
column20: for each tree exists a depth-first search from the node with number 1
column21: that visits leaves in order of connection to devices 1
column23: \xe2\x80\xa6
column24: n (firstly
column25: the node
column26: that is connected to the device 1
column27: then the node
column28: that is connected to the device 2
column29: etc.).Businessman wants to sell (remove) maximal amount of wires so that each device will be powered from at least one grid (main or reserve). In other words
column30: for each device should exist at least one path to the head node (in the main grid or the reserve grid)
column31: which contains only nodes from one grid." 2400

column2: implementation" "The development of a text editor is a hard problem. You need to implement an extra module for brackets coloring in text.Your editor consists of a line with infinite length and cursor
column3: which points to the current character. Please note that it points to only one of the characters (and not between a pair of characters). Thus
column4: it points to an index character. The user can move the cursor left or right one position. If the cursor is already at the first (leftmost) position
column5: then it does not move left.Initially
column6: the cursor is in the first (leftmost) character.Also
column7: the user can write a letter or brackets (either (
column8: or )) to the position that the cursor is currently pointing at. A new character always overwrites the old value at that position.Your editor must check
column9: whether the current line is the correct text. Text is correct if the brackets in them form the correct bracket sequence.Formally
column10: correct text (CT) must satisfy the following rules:   any line without brackets is CT (the line can contain whitespaces);  If the first character of the string \xe2\x80\x94 is (
column11: the last \xe2\x80\x94 is )
column12: and all the rest form a CT
column13: then the whole line is a CT;  two consecutively written CT is also CT. Examples of correct texts: hello(codeforces)
column14: round
column15: ((i)(write))edi(tor)s
column16: ( me). Examples of incorrect texts: hello)oops(
column17: round)
column18: ((me).The user uses special commands to work with your editor. Each command has its symbol
column19: which must be written to execute this command.The correspondence of commands and characters is as follows:   L \xe2\x80\x94 move the cursor one character to the left (remains in place if it already points to the first character);  R \xe2\x80\x94 move the cursor one character to the right;  any lowercase Latin letter or bracket (( or )) \xe2\x80\x94 write the entered character to the position where the cursor is now. For a complete understanding
column20: take a look at the first example and its illustrations in the note below.You are given a string containing the characters that the user entered. For the brackets coloring module\'s work
column21: after each command you need to:  check if the current text in the editor is a correct text;  if it is
column22: print the least number of colors that required
column23: to color all brackets. If two pairs of brackets are nested (the first in the second or vice versa)
column24: then these pairs of brackets should be painted in different colors. If two pairs of brackets are not nested
column25: then they can be painted in different or the same colors. For example
column26: for the bracket sequence ()(())()() the least number of colors is 2
column27: and for the bracket sequence (()(()())())(()) \xe2\x80\x94 is 3.Write a program that prints the minimal number of colors after processing each command." 2100

column3: graphs" "One unknown hacker wants to get the admin\'s password of AtForces testing system

He found that the system contains only passwords from the stolen list and that the system determines the equivalence of the passwords a and b as follows:  two passwords a and b are equivalent if there is a letter
column7: that exists in both a and b;  two passwords a and b are equivalent if there is a password c from the list
column8: which is equivalent to both a and b. If a password is set in the system and an equivalent one is applied to access the system
column9: then the user is accessed into the system.For example
column10: if the list contain passwords ""a""
column14: then passwords ""a""
column16: ""ab"" are equivalent to each other
column17: but the password ""d"" is not equivalent to any other password from list. In other words
column18: if:  admin\'s password is ""b""
column19: then you can access to system by using any of this passwords: ""a""
column21: ""ab"";  admin\'s password is ""d""
column22: then you can access to system by using only ""d"". Only one password from the list is the admin\'s password from the testing system. Help hacker to calculate the minimal number of passwords
column23: required to guaranteed access to the system. Keep in mind that the hacker does not know which password is set in the system." 1500

column4: number theory" "On the well-known testing system MathForces

column13: then none of the participants will increase their rating.Vasya participates in this rating draw but does not have information on the total number of participants in this event. Therefore
column14: he wants to know what different values of the rating increment are possible to get as a result of this draw and asks you for help.For example
column15: if n=5
column16: then the answer is equal to the sequence 0
column19: 5. Each of the sequence values (and only them) can be obtained as \xe2\x8c\x8an/k\xe2\x8c\x8b for some positive integer k (where \xe2\x8c\x8ax\xe2\x8c\x8b is the value of x rounded down): 0=\xe2\x8c\x8a5/7\xe2\x8c\x8b

column21: 2=\xe2\x8c\x8a5/2\xe2\x8c\x8b
column22: 5=\xe2\x8c\x8a5/1\xe2\x8c\x8b.Write a program that
column23: for a given n
column24: finds a sequence of all possible rating increments." 1400

column2: implementation "A PIN code is a string that consists of exactly 4 digits. Examples of possible PIN codes: 7013

column4: even with 0.Polycarp has n (2\xe2\x89\xa4n\xe2\x89\xa410) bank cards
column5: the PIN code of the i-th card is pi.Polycarp has recently read a recommendation that it is better to set different PIN codes on different cards. Thus he wants to change the minimal number of digits in the PIN codes of his cards so that all n codes would become different.Formally
column6: in one step
column7: Polycarp picks i-th card (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n)
column8: then in its PIN code pi selects one position (from 1 to 4)
column9: and changes the digit in this position to any other. He needs to change the minimum number of digits so that all PIN codes become different.Polycarp quickly solved this problem. Can you solve it?" 1400

column6: so city i proposes to add a direct bidirectional road connecting city i and city Ai. It is guaranteed that no two cities like to connect with each other. In other words
column7: there is no pair of integers i and j where Ai=j and Aj=i. It is also guaranteed that any pair of cities are connected by a sequence of road proposals. In other words
column8: if all proposed roads are constructed

column10: 0 for asphalt

column17: the ith worker can only construct a road with material Ci. Each worker can only construct at most one road. You want to assign each worker to construct a road such that any pair of cities are connected by a sequence of constructed road." 2300

column2: dp" "Talia has just bought an abandoned house in the outskirt of Jakarta. The house has a nice and long yard which can be represented as a one-dimensional grid containing 1\xc3\x97N cells. To beautify the house
column3: Talia is going to build a terrace on the yard by tiling the cells. Each cell on the yard contains either soil (represented by the character \'.\') or rock (represented by the character \'#\')
column4: and there are at most 50 cells containing rocks.Being a superstitious person
column5: Talia wants to tile the terrace with mystical tiles that have the power to repel ghosts. There are three types of mystical tiles:   Type-1: Covers 1\xc3\x971 cell and can only be placed on a soil cell (""."").  Type-2: Covers 1\xc3\x972 cells and can only be placed on two consecutive soil cells ("".."").  Type-3: Covers 1\xc3\x973 cells and can only be placed on consecutive soil-rock-soil cells ("".#.""). Each tile of Type-1
column6: Type-2
column7: and Type-3 has the power to repel G1
column8: G2
column9: and G3 ghosts per day
column10: respectively. There are also some mystical rules which must be followed for the power to be effective:   There should be no overlapping tiles
column11: i.e. each cell is covered by at most one tile.  There should be at most K tiles of Type-1
column12: while there are no limitations for tiles of Type-2 and Type-3. Talia is scared of ghosts
column13: thus
column14: the terrace (which is tiled by mystical tiles) should be able to repel as many ghosts as possible. Help Talia to find the maximum number of ghosts that can be repelled per day by the terrace. Note that Talia does not need to tile all the cells on the yard as long as the number of ghosts that can be repelled by the terrace is maximum." 2300

column2: trees "A forestation is an act of planting a bunch of trees to grow a forest
column3: usually to replace a forest that had been cut down. Strangely enough
column4: graph theorists have another idea on how to make a forest
column5: i.e. by cutting down a tree!A tree is a graph of N nodes connected by N\xe2\x88\x921 edges. Let u be a node in a tree U which degree is at least 2 (i.e. directly connected to at least 2 other nodes in U). If we remove u from U
column6: then we will get two or more disconnected (smaller) trees
column7: or also known as forest by graph theorists. In this problem
column8: we are going to investigate a special forestation of a tree done by graph theorists.Let V(S) be the set of nodes in a tree S and V(T) be the set of nodes in a tree T. Tree S and tree T are identical if there exists a bijection f:V(S)\xe2\x86\x92V(T) such that for all pairs of nodes (si
column9: sj) in V(S)
column10: si and sj is connected by an edge in S if and only if node f(si) and f(sj) is connected by an edge in T. Note that f(s)=t implies node s in S corresponds to node t in T.We call a node u in a tree U as a good cutting point if and only if the removal of u from U causes two or more disconnected trees
column11: and all those disconnected trees are pairwise identical.Given a tree U
column12: your task is to determine whether there exists a good cutting point in U. If there is such a node
column13: then you should output the maximum number of disconnected trees that can be obtained by removing exactly one good cutting point.For example
column14: consider the following tree of 13 nodes.There is exactly one good cutting point in this tree
column15: i.e. node 4. Observe that by removing node 4
column16: we will get three identical trees (in this case
column17: line graphs)
column32: and C respectively in the figure.   The bijection function between A and B: f(5)=8

column38: and f(13)=10.  The bijection function between B and C: f(8)=3
column41: and f(6)=10.  Of course
column42: there exists other bijection functions for those trees." 2400

column1: 1252A "Copying Homework" NA "Danang and Darto are classmates. They are given homework to create a permutation of N integers from 1 to N. Danang has completed the homework and created a permutation A of N integers. Darto wants to copy Danang\'s homework
column2: but Danang asks Darto to change it up a bit so it does not look obvious that Darto copied.The difference of two permutations of N integers A and B
column3: denoted by diff(A
column4: B)
column5: is the sum of the absolute difference of Ai and Bi for all i. In other words
column6: diff(A
column7: B)=\xce\xa3Ni=1|Ai\xe2\x88\x92Bi|. Darto would like to create a permutation of N integers that maximizes its difference with A. Formally
column8: he wants to find a permutation of N integers Bmax such that diff(A
column9: Bmax)\xe2\x89\xa5diff(A
column10: B\xe2\x80\xb2) for all permutation of N integers B\xe2\x80\xb2.Darto needs your help! Since the teacher giving the homework is lenient
column11: any permutation of N integers B is considered different with A if the difference of A and B is at least N. Therefore
column12: you are allowed to return any permutation of N integers B such that diff(A
column13: B)\xe2\x89\xa5N.Of course
column14: you can still return Bmax if you want
column15: since it can be proven that diff(A
column16: Bmax)\xe2\x89\xa5N for any permutation A and N>1. This also proves that there exists a solution for any permutation of N integers A. If there is more than one valid solution
column17: you can output any of them." 1000

column3: greedy" "Polycarpus has a complex electronic device. The core of this device is a circuit board. The board has 109 contact points which are numbered from 1 to 109. Also there are n wires numbered from 1 to n

I.e. it takes one minute to change one of the two contact points for a wire. Any contact point from range [1
column12: 109] can be used as a new contact point. A wire\'s ends must always be soldered to distinct contact points. Both wire\'s ends can be re-solded
column13: but that will require two actions and will take 2 minutes in total.Find the minimum amount of time Polycarpus needs to re-solder wires so that a signal can pass between any pair of wires. Also output an optimal sequence of wire re-soldering." 2000

column2: divide and conquer" "Berland Gardeners United Inc. hired you for the project called ""SmartGarden"". The main feature of this project is automatic garden watering.Formally the garden can be represented as a square of n\xc3\x97n cells with rows numbered 1 to n from top to bottom and columns numbered 1 to n from left to right. Each cell of the garden contains either a plant or a slab. It\'s known that slabs are located on the main diagonal of the matrix representing the garden
column3: and in the cells that are below the main diagonal and share a side with at least one cell of the main diagonal. All the remaining cells of the garden are filled with plants.  Example of the garden for n=5. During implementation of the project you created a smart robot that takes a list of commands as an input
column4: which are processed one by one. Each command contains:   a list of horizontal lines (rows in the matrix representing the garden);  a list of vertical lines (columns in the matrix representing the garden). While executing each command robot waters only cells in the intersection of specified rows and specified columns. So
column5: if you specify r rows and c columns
column6: then exactly r\xe2\x8b\x85c cells will be watered.In the demo for the customer you have tuned robot in such a way that it waters all the garden. To do that you prepared a single command containing all n rows and all n columns.Unfortunately
column7: 5 hours before the demo for your customer it turned out that the CEO of Berland Gardeners United Inc. was going to take part in it. Moreover
column8: most probably he will be standing on a garden slab during the demo!Now you need to create a list of commands for the robot so that it waters all the plants and doesn\'t water any cell containing a slab. Since it\'s only a beta version of ""SmartGarden""
column9: the total number of commands shouldn\'t exceed 50.Create a program that
column10: for a given size of the garden
column11: will find a list of no more than 50 commands that allow the robot to water all the plants in the garden without watering the slabs. It is allowed to water a plant several times." 2500

column4: shortest paths" "The director of the famous dance show plans a tour. It is already decided that the tour will consist of up to m concerts.There are n dancers in the troupe. Each dancer is characterized by her awkwardness: the awkwardness of the i-th dancer is equal to ai.The director likes diversity. For this reason
column5: each concert will be performed by a different set of dancers. A dancer may perform in multiple concerts. For example
column6: it is possible that a set of dancers performs in one concert and a subset of this set of dancers performs in another concert. The only constraint is that the same set of dancers cannot perform twice.The director prefers the set with larger number of dancers over the set with smaller number of dancers. If two sets consist of the same number of dancers
column7: then the director prefers the one which has smaller sum of awkwardness of dancers. If two sets of dancers are equal in size and total awkwardness
column8: then the director does not have a preference which one is better.A marketing study shows that viewers are not ready to come to a concert if the total awkwardness of all the dancers performing in the concert is greater than k.The director wants to find the best plan for m concerts. He thinks to write down all possible sets of dancers; then get rid of the sets with total awkwardness greater than k. The remaining sets of dancers will be sorted according to his preference. The most preferred set of dancers will give the first concert
column9: the second preferred set \xe2\x80\x94 the second concert and so on until the m-th concert. If it turns out that the total number of valid sets is less than m
column10: then the total number of concerts will be equal to the number of valid sets.It turns out that the director delegated finding the plan to you! Please
column11: notice that there might be several acceptable plans due to the fact that the director does not have a preference over sets of dancers with the same size and total awkwardness. In this case any of these plans is good enough. For each concert find the number of dancers and the total awkwardness of the set performing. Also
column12: for the last concert find its set of dancers." 3100

column7: candles don\'t have time to burn out. For this reason you can reuse candles an arbitrary number of times (therefore your set of candles never changes).For example

column13: but y cannot be composed." 1500

column4: meet-in-the-middle" "The only difference between easy and hard versions is the maximum value of n.You are given a positive integer number n. You really love good numbers so you want to find the smallest good number greater than or equal to n.The positive integer is called good if it can be represented as a sum of distinct powers of 3 (i.e. no duplicates of powers of 3 are allowed).For example:  30 is a good number: 30=33+31
column5: 1 is a good number: 1=30
column6: 12 is a good number: 12=32+31
column7: but 2 is not a good number: you can\'t represent it as a sum of distinct powers of 3 (2=30+30)
column8: 19 is not a good number: you can\'t represent it as a sum of distinct powers of 3 (for example
column9: the representations 19=32+32+30=32+31+31+31+30 are invalid)
column10: 20 is also not a good number: you can\'t represent it as a sum of distinct powers of 3 (for example
column11: the representation 20=32+32+30+30 is invalid). Note
column12: that there exist other representations of 19 and 20 as sums of powers of 3 but none of them consists of distinct powers of 3.For the given positive integer n find such smallest m (n\xe2\x89\xa4m) that m is a good number.You have to answer q independent queries." 1500

column8: he gets the correct answer
column9: 5. Puzzled by this mystery
column10: he opened up his calculator and found the answer to the riddle: the full adders became half adders! So
column11: when he tries to compute the sum a+b using the calculator
column12: he instead gets the xorsum a\xe2\x8a\x95b (read the definition by the link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exclusive_or).As he saw earlier
column13: the calculator sometimes gives the correct answer. And so
column14: he wonders
column15: given integers l and r
column16: how many pairs of integers (a
column17: b) satisfy the following conditions: a+b=a\xe2\x8a\x95b l\xe2\x89\xa4a\xe2\x89\xa4r l\xe2\x89\xa4b\xe2\x89\xa4rHowever
column18: Daniel the Barman is going to the bar and will return in two hours. He tells you to solve the problem before he returns

column3: shortest paths" "Hyakugoku has just retired from being the resident deity of the South Black Snail Temple in order to pursue her dream of becoming a cartoonist. She spent six months in that temple just playing ""Cat\'s Cradle"" so now she wants to try a different game \xe2\x80\x94 ""Snakes and Ladders"". Unfortunately
column4: she already killed all the snakes
column5: so there are only ladders left now. The game is played on a 10\xc3\x9710 board as follows:  At the beginning of the game
column6: the player is at the bottom left square.  The objective of the game is for the player to reach the Goal (the top left square) by following the path and climbing vertical ladders. Once the player reaches the Goal
column7: the game ends.  The path is as follows: if a square is not the end of its row
column8: it leads to the square next to it along the direction of its row; if a square is the end of its row
column9: it leads to the square above it. The direction of a row is determined as follows: the direction of the bottom row is to the right; the direction of any other row is opposite the direction of the row below it. See Notes section for visualization of path.  During each turn
column10: the player rolls a standard six-sided dice. Suppose that the number shown on the dice is r. If the Goal is less than r squares away on the path
column11: the player doesn\'t move (but the turn is performed). Otherwise
column12: the player advances exactly r squares along the path and then stops. If the player stops on a square with the bottom of a ladder
column13: the player chooses whether or not to climb up that ladder. If she chooses not to climb
column14: then she stays in that square for the beginning of the next turn.  Some squares have a ladder in them. Ladders are only placed vertically \xe2\x80\x94 each one leads to the same square of some of the upper rows. In order for the player to climb up a ladder
column15: after rolling the dice
column16: she must stop at the square containing the bottom of the ladder. After using the ladder
column17: the player will end up in the square containing the top of the ladder. She cannot leave the ladder in the middle of climbing. And if the square containing the top of the ladder also contains the bottom of another ladder
column18: she is not allowed to use that second ladder.  The numbers on the faces of the dice are 1
column23: and 6
column24: with each number having the same probability of being shown. Please note that:     it is possible for ladders to overlap
column25: but the player cannot switch to the other ladder while in the middle of climbing the first one;     it is possible for ladders to go straight to the top row
column26: but not any higher;     it is possible for two ladders to lead to the same tile;     it is possible for a ladder to lead to a tile that also has a ladder
column27: but the player will not be able to use that second ladder if she uses the first one;     the player can only climb up ladders
column28: not climb down. Hyakugoku wants to finish the game as soon as possible. Thus
column29: on each turn she chooses whether to climb the ladder or not optimally. Help her to determine the minimum expected number of turns the game will take." 2300

column1: 1245C "Constanze\'s Machine" dp "Constanze is the smartest girl in her village but she has bad eyesight.One day
column2: she was able to invent an incredible machine! When you pronounce letters

column4: if you pronounce \'c\'
column7: and \'e\' in that order

column9: she can finally write messages without using her glasses.However

column11: it will inscribe ""uu"" instead of ""w""
column12: and if you pronounce \'m\'
column13: it will inscribe ""nn"" instead of ""m""! Since Constanze had bad eyesight

column15: the machine will just inscribe it onto a piece of paper.The next day
column16: I received a letter in my mailbox. I can\'t understand it so I think it\'s either just some gibberish from Akko
column17: or Constanze made it using her machine. But since I know what Akko did
column18: I can just list down all possible strings that Constanze\'s machine would have turned into the message I got and see if anything makes sense.But I need to know how much paper I will need
column19: and that\'s why I\'m asking you for help. Tell me the number of strings that Constanze\'s machine would\'ve turned into the message I got.But since this number can be quite large
column20: tell me instead its remainder when divided by 109+7.If there are no strings that Constanze\'s machine would\'ve turned into the message I got
column21: then print 0." 1400

Is it possible to make x equal to y?Recall that a prime number is a positive integer that has exactly two positive divisors: 1 and this integer itself. The sequence of prime numbers starts with 2
column6: 11.Your program should solve t independent test cases." 900

column1: 1237H "Balanced Reversals" "constructive algorithms" "You have two strings a and b of equal even length n consisting of characters 0 and 1.We\'re in the endgame now. To finally make the universe perfectly balanced
column2: you need to make strings a and b equal.In one step
column3: you can choose any prefix of a of even length and reverse it. Formally
column4: if a=a1a2\xe2\x80\xa6an
column5: you can choose a positive even integer p\xe2\x89\xa4n and set a to apap\xe2\x88\x921\xe2\x80\xa6a1ap+1ap+2\xe2\x80\xa6an.Find a way to make a equal to b using at most n+1 reversals of the above kind
column6: or determine that such a way doesn\'t exist. The number of reversals doesn\'t have to be minimized." 3300

column3: greedy" "There are n friends living on a circular street. The friends and their houses are numbered clockwise from 0 to n\xe2\x88\x921.Initially person i has ai stones. The friends want to make the distribution of stones among them perfectly balanced: everyone should possess the same number of stones.The only way to change the distribution of stones is by conducting meetings. During a meeting
column4: people from exactly k consecutive houses (remember that the street is circular) gather at the same place and bring all their stones with them. All brought stones may be redistributed among people attending the meeting arbitrarily. The total number of stones they possess before the meeting and after the meeting must stay the same. After the meeting
column5: everyone returns to their home.Find a way to make the distribution of stones perfectly balanced conducting as few meetings as possible." 3500

column2: dp "Consider a square grid with h rows and w columns with some dominoes on it. Each domino covers exactly two cells of the grid that share a common side. Every cell is covered by at most one domino.Let\'s call a placement of dominoes on the grid perfectly balanced if no row and no column contains a pair of cells covered by two different dominoes. In other words
column3: every row and column may contain no covered cells
column4: one covered cell
column5: or two covered cells that belong to the same domino.You are given a perfectly balanced placement of dominoes on a grid. Find the number of ways to place zero or more extra dominoes on this grid to keep the placement perfectly balanced. Output this number modulo 998244353." 2600

column2: math "Recall that a binary search tree is a rooted binary tree
column3: whose nodes each store a key and each have at most two distinguished subtrees
column4: left and right. The key in each node must be greater than any key stored in the left subtree
column5: and less than any key stored in the right subtree.The depth of a vertex is the number of edges on the simple path from the vertex to the root. In particular
column6: the depth of the root is 0.Let\'s call a binary search tree perfectly balanced if there doesn\'t exist a binary search tree with the same number of vertices that has a strictly smaller sum of depths of its vertices.Let\'s call a binary search tree with integer keys striped if both of the following conditions are satisfied for every vertex v:   If v has a left subtree whose root is u
column7: then the parity of the key of v is different from the parity of the key of u.  If v has a right subtree whose root is w
column8: then the parity of the key of v is the same as the parity of the key of w. You are given a single integer n. Find the number of perfectly balanced striped binary search trees with n vertices that have distinct integer keys between 1 and n
column9: inclusive. Output this number modulo 998244353." 2400

column3: implementation" "Your favorite music streaming platform has formed a perfectly balanced playlist exclusively for you. The playlist consists of n tracks numbered from 1 to n. The playlist is automatic and cyclic: whenever track i finishes playing
column4: track i+1 starts playing automatically; after track n goes track 1.For each track i
column5: you have estimated its coolness ai. The higher ai is
column6: the cooler track i is.Every morning
column7: you choose a track. The playlist then starts playing from this track in its usual cyclic fashion. At any moment
column8: you remember the maximum coolness x of already played tracks. Once you hear that a track with coolness strictly less than x2 (no rounding) starts playing
column9: you turn off the music immediately to keep yourself in a good mood.For each track i
column10: find out how many tracks you will listen to before turning off the music if you start your morning with track i
column11: or determine that you will never turn the music off. Note that if you listen to the same track several times
column12: every time must be counted." 2000

column3: two pointers" "Consider a tunnel on a one-way road. During a particular day
column4: n cars numbered from 1 to n entered and exited the tunnel exactly once. Perfectly balanced.Thanks to the cameras
column5: the order in which the cars entered and exited the tunnel is known. No two cars entered or exited at the same time.Traffic regulations prohibit overtaking inside the tunnel. If car i overtakes any other car j inside the tunnel
column6: car i must be fined. However

column9: car i must be fined if and only if it definitely overtook at least one other car.Find the number of cars that must be fined." 1300

column2: math "Alice got many presents these days. So she decided to pack them into boxes and send them to her friends.There are n kinds of presents. Presents of one kind are identical (i.e. there is no way to distinguish two gifts of the same kind). Presents of different kinds are different (i.e. that is
column3: two gifts of different kinds are distinguishable). The number of presents of each kind
column4: that Alice has is very big
column5: so we can consider Alice has an infinite number of gifts of each kind.Also
column6: there are m boxes. All of them are for different people
column7: so they are pairwise distinct (consider that the names of m friends are written on the boxes). For example
column8: putting the first kind of present into the first box but not into the second box
column9: is different from putting the first kind of present into the second box but not into the first box.Alice wants to pack presents with the following rules:  She won\'t pack more than one present of each kind into the same box
column10: so each box should contain presents of different kinds (i.e. each box contains a subset of n kinds
column11: empty boxes are allowed);  For each kind at least one present should be packed into some box. Now Alice wants to know how many different ways to pack the presents exists. Please
column12: help her and calculate this number. Since the answer can be huge
column13: output it by modulo 109+7.See examples and their notes for clarification." 1500

column2: implementation" "The only difference between easy and hard versions are constraints on n and k.You are messaging in one of the popular social networks via your smartphone. Your smartphone can show at most k most recent conversations with your friends. Initially
column3: the screen is empty (i.e. the number of displayed conversations equals 0).Each conversation is between you and some of your friends. There is at most one conversation with any of your friends. So each conversation is uniquely defined by your friend.You (suddenly!) have the ability to see the future. You know that during the day you will receive n messages
column4: the i-th message will be received from the friend with ID idi (1\xe2\x89\xa4idi\xe2\x89\xa4109).If you receive a message from idi in the conversation which is currently displayed on the smartphone then nothing happens: the conversations of the screen do not change and do not change their order
column5: you read the message and continue waiting for new messages.Otherwise (i.e. if there is no conversation with idi on the screen):  Firstly
column6: if the number of conversations displayed on the screen is k
column7: the last conversation (which has the position k) is removed from the screen.  Now the number of conversations on the screen is guaranteed to be less than k and the conversation with the friend idi is not displayed on the screen.  The conversation with the friend idi appears on the first (the topmost) position on the screen and all the other displayed conversations are shifted one position down. Your task is to find the list of conversations (in the order they are displayed on the screen) after processing all n messages." 1300

column1: 1234A "Equalize Prices Again" math "You are both a shop keeper and a shop assistant at a small nearby shop. You have n goods

column7: you will receive at least the same (or greater) amount of money as if you sell them for their initial prices.You have to answer q independent queries." 800

For example
column11: bracket sequences ""()()""
column12: ""(())"" are regular (the resulting expressions are: ""(1)+(1)""

column3: trees" "Bytelandian Tree Factory produces trees for all kinds of industrial applications. You have been tasked with optimizing the production of a certain type of tree for an especially large and important order.The tree in question is a rooted tree with n vertices labelled with distinct integers from 0 to n\xe2\x88\x921. The vertex labelled 0 is the root of the tree
column4: and for any non-root vertex v the label of its parent p(v) is less than the label of v.All trees at the factory are made from bamboo blanks. A bamboo is a rooted tree such that each vertex has exactly one child
column5: except for a single leaf vertex with no children. The vertices of a bamboo blank can be labelled arbitrarily before its processing is started.To process a bamboo into another tree a single type of operation can be made: choose an arbitrary non-root vertex v such that its parent p(v) is not a root either. The operation consists of changing the parent of v to its parent\'s parent p(p(v)). Note that parents of all other vertices remain unchanged
column6: in particular
column7: the subtree of v does not change.Efficiency is crucial
column8: hence you have to minimize the number of operations to make the desired tree from a bamboo blank. Construct any optimal sequence of operations to produce the desired tree.Note that the labelling of the resulting tree has to coincide with the labelling of the desired tree. Formally
column9: the labels of the roots have to be equal
column10: and for non-root vertices with the same label the labels of their parents should be the same.It is guaranteed that for any test present in this problem an answer exists
column11: and further
column12: an optimal sequence contains at most 106 operations. Note that any hack that does not meet these conditions will be invalid." 2500

column2: dp" "You are at the top left cell (1

column4: m). You can only move right or down
column5: one cell per step. Moving right from a cell (x
column6: y) takes you to the cell (x
column8: while moving down takes you to the cell (x+1
column9: y).Some cells of the labyrinth contain rocks. When you move to a cell with rock
column10: the rock is pushed to the next cell in the direction you\'re moving. If the next cell contains a rock
column11: it gets pushed further
column12: and so on.The labyrinth is surrounded by impenetrable walls
column13: thus any move that would put you or any rock outside of the labyrinth is illegal.Count the number of different legal paths you can take from the start to the goal modulo 109+7. Two paths are considered different if there is at least one cell that is visited in one path
column14: but not visited in the other." 2200

column12: for every color

column7: while all wires look the same and are indistinguishable. In order to complete this construction set one has to use each of the wires to connect two distinct bulbs. We define a chain in a completed construction set as a sequence of distinct bulbs of length at least two
column8: such that every two consecutive bulbs in this sequence are directly connected by a wire. Completed construction set configuration is said to be correct if a resulting network of bulbs and wires has a tree structure
column9: i.e. any two distinct bulbs are the endpoints of some chain.Petya was assembling different configurations for several days
column10: and he noticed that sometimes some of the bulbs turn on. After a series of experiments he came up with a conclusion that bulbs indexed 2i and 2i\xe2\x88\x921 turn on if the chain connecting them consists of exactly di wires. Moreover

column2: greedy" "Marcin is a coach in his university. There are n students who want to attend a training camp. Marcin is a smart coach
column3: so he wants to send only the students that can work calmly with each other.Let\'s focus on the students. They are indexed with integers from 1 to n. Each of them can be described with two integers ai and bi; bi is equal to the skill level of the i-th student (the higher
column4: the better). Also
column5: there are 60 known algorithms
column6: which are numbered with integers from 0 to 59. If the i-th student knows the j-th algorithm
column7: then the j-th bit (2j) is set in the binary representation of ai. Otherwise
column8: this bit is not set.Student x thinks that he is better than student y if and only if x knows some algorithm which y doesn\'t know. Note that two students can think that they are better than each other. A group of students can work together calmly if no student in this group thinks that he is better than everyone else in this group.Marcin wants to send a group of at least two students which will work together calmly and will have the maximum possible sum of the skill levels. What is this sum?" 1700

column2: graphs" "Anadi has a set of dominoes. Every domino has two parts
column3: and each part contains some dots. For every aa and bb such that 1\xe2\x89\xa4a\xe2\x89\xa4b\xe2\x89\xa461\xe2\x89\xa4a\xe2\x89\xa4b\xe2\x89\xa46
column4: there is exactly one domino with aa dots on one half and bb dots on the other half. The set contains exactly 2121 dominoes. Here is an exact illustration of his set:  Also
column5: Anadi has an undirected graph without self-loops and multiple edges. He wants to choose some dominoes and place them on the edges of this graph. He can use at most one domino of each type. Each edge can fit at most one domino. It\'s not necessary to place a domino on each edge of the graph.When placing a domino on an edge
column6: he also chooses its direction. In other words
column7: one half of any placed domino must be directed toward one of the endpoints of the edge and the other half must be directed toward the other endpoint. There\'s a catch: if there are multiple halves of dominoes directed toward the same vertex
column8: each of these halves must contain the same number of dots.How many dominoes at most can Anadi place on the edges of his graph?" 1700

column3: math" "Airports often use moving walkways to help you walking big distances faster. Each such walkway has some speed that effectively increases your speed. You can stand on such a walkway and let it move you
column4: or you could also walk and then your effective speed is your walking speed plus walkway\'s speed.Limak wants to get from point 0 to point L on a straight line. There are n disjoint walkways in between. The i-th walkway is described by two integers xi and yi and a real value si. The i-th walkway starts at xi
column5: ends at yi and has speed si. Every walkway is located inside the segment [0
column6: L] and no two walkways have positive intersection. However
column7: they can touch by endpoints.Limak needs to decide how to distribute his energy. For example
column8: it might make more sense to stand somewhere (or to walk slowly) to then have a lot of energy to walk faster.Limak\'s initial energy is 0 and it must never drop below that value. At any moment
column9: he can walk with any speed v in the interval [0
column10: 2] and it will cost him v energy per second
column11: but he continuously recovers energy with speed of 1 energy per second. So
column12: when he walks with speed v
column13: his energy increases by (1\xe2\x88\x92v). Note that negative value would mean losing energy.In particular
column14: he can walk with speed 1 and this won\'t change his energy at all
column15: while walking with speed 0.77 effectively gives him 0.23 energy per second.Limak can choose his speed arbitrarily (any real value in interval [0
column16: 2]) at every moment of time (including the moments when he is located on non-integer positions). Everything is continuous (non-discrete).What is the fastest time Limak can get from 0 to L?" 3300

column1: 1203A "Circle of Students" implementation "There are n students standing in a circle in some order. The index of the i-th student is pi. A clockwise round dance can be started if the student 2 comes right after the student 1 in clockwise order (there are no students between them)
column2: the student 3 comes right after the student 2 in clockwise order
column3: and so on
column4: and the student n comes right after the student n\xe2\x88\x921 in clockwise order. A counterclockwise round dance is almost the same thing \xe2\x80\x94 the only difference is that the student i should be right after the student i\xe2\x88\x921 in counterclockwise order (this condition should be met for every i from 2 to n). For example
column5: if the indices of students listed in clockwise order are [2
column10: then they can start a clockwise round dance. If the students have indices [3
column13: 4] in clockwise order
column14: then they can start a counterclockwise round dance.Your task is to determine whether it is possible to start a round dance. Note that the students cannot change their positions before starting the dance; they cannot swap or leave the circle
column15: and no other student can enter the circle. You have to answer q independent queries." 1000

column9: there is a directed graph consisting of n vertices numbered from 1 to n. The i-th vertex has mi outgoing edges that are labeled as ei[0]
column10: ei[1]
column11: \xe2\x80\xa6
column12: ei[mi\xe2\x88\x921]
column13: each representing the destination vertex of the edge. The graph can have multiple edges and self-loops. The i-th vertex also has an integer ki written on itself.A travel on this graph works as follows.   Gildong chooses a vertex to start from
column14: and an integer to start with. Set the variable c to this integer.  After arriving at the vertex i
column15: or when Gildong begins the travel at some vertex i
column16: add ki to c.  The next vertex is ei[x] where x is an integer 0\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa4mi\xe2\x88\x921 satisfying x\xe2\x89\xa1c(modmi). Go to the next vertex and go back to step 2. It\'s obvious that a travel never ends
column17: since the 2nd and the 3rd step will be repeated endlessly.For example
column18: assume that Gildong starts at vertex 1 with c=5
column19: and m1=2
column22: k1=\xe2\x88\x923. Right after he starts at vertex 1
column23: c becomes 2. Since the only integer x (0\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa41) where x\xe2\x89\xa1c(modmi) is 0
column24: Gildong goes to vertex e1[0]=1. After arriving at vertex 1 again
column25: c becomes \xe2\x88\x921. The only integer x satisfying the conditions is 1
column26: so he goes to vertex e1[1]=2
column27: and so on.Since Gildong is quite inquisitive
column28: he\'s going to ask you q queries. He wants to know how many distinct vertices will be visited infinitely many times
column29: if he starts the travel from a certain vertex with a certain value of c. Note that you should not count the vertices that will be visited only finite times." 2300

column2: greedy "Gildong is playing a video game called Block Adventure. In Block Adventure
column3: there are n columns of blocks in a row
column4: and the columns are numbered from 1 to n. All blocks have equal heights. The height of the i-th column is represented as hi
column5: which is the number of blocks stacked in the i-th column.Gildong plays the game as a character that can stand only on the top of the columns. At the beginning
column6: the character is standing on the top of the 1-st column. The goal of the game is to move the character to the top of the n-th column.The character also has a bag that can hold infinitely many blocks. When the character is on the top of the i-th column
column7: Gildong can take one of the following three actions as many times as he wants:   if there is at least one block on the column
column8: remove one block from the top of the i-th column and put it in the bag;  if there is at least one block in the bag
column9: take one block out of the bag and place it on the top of the i-th column;  if i<n and |hi\xe2\x88\x92hi+1|\xe2\x89\xa4k
column10: move the character to the top of the i+1-st column. k is a non-negative integer given at the beginning of the game. Note that it is only possible to move to the next column. In actions of the first two types the character remains in the i-th column
column11: and the value hi changes.The character initially has m blocks in the bag. Gildong wants to know if it is possible to win the game. Help Gildong find the answer to his question." 1200

column2: two pointers" "One common way of digitalizing sound is to record sound intensity at particular time moments. For each time moment intensity is recorded as a non-negative integer. Thus we can represent a sound file as an array of n non-negative integers.If there are exactly K distinct values in the array
column3: then we need k=\xe2\x8c\x88log2K\xe2\x8c\x89 bits to store each value. It then takes nk bits to store the whole file.To reduce the memory consumption we need to apply some compression. One common way is to reduce the number of possible intensity values. We choose two integers l\xe2\x89\xa4r
column4: and after that all intensity values are changed in the following way: if the intensity value is within the range [l;r]
column5: we don\'t change it. If it is less than l
column6: we change it to l; if it is greater than r
column7: we change it to r. You can see that we lose some low and some high intensities.Your task is to apply this compression in such a way that the file fits onto a disk of size I bytes
column8: and the number of changed elements in the array is minimal possible.We remind you that 1 byte contains 8 bits.k=\xe2\x8c\x88log2K\xe2\x8c\x89 is the smallest integer such that K\xe2\x89\xa42k. In particular
column9: if K=1

column3: matrices "Alice and Bob want to play a game. They have n colored paper strips; the i-th strip is divided into ai cells numbered from 1 to ai. Each cell can have one of 3 colors.In the beginning of the game
column4: Alice and Bob put n chips
column5: the i-th chip is put in the ai-th cell of the i-th strip. Then they take turns
column6: Alice is first. Each player during their turn has to choose one chip and move it 1
column7: 2 or 3 cells backwards (i.\xe2\x80\x89e. if the current cell is x
column8: then the chip can be moved to the cell x\xe2\x88\x921
column9: x\xe2\x88\x922 or x\xe2\x88\x923). There are two restrictions: the chip cannot leave the borders of the strip (for example
column10: if the current cell is 3
column11: then you can\'t move the chip 3 cells backwards); and some moves may be prohibited because of color of the current cell (a matrix f with size 3\xc3\x973 is given
column12: where fi
column13: j=1 if it is possible to move the chip j cells backwards from the cell which has color i
column14: or fi
column15: j=0 if such move is prohibited). The player who cannot make a move loses the game.Initially some cells may be uncolored. Bob can color all uncolored cells as he wants (but he cannot leave any cell uncolored). Let\'s call a coloring good if Bob can win the game no matter how Alice acts
column16: if the cells are colored according to this coloring. Two colorings are different if at least one cell is colored in different colors in these two colorings.Bob wants you to calculate the number of good colorings. Can you do it for him?Since the answer can be really large
column17: you have to print it modulo 998244353." 2700

column6: sortings" "There are famous Russian nesting dolls named matryoshkas sold in one of the souvenir stores nearby
column7: and you\'d like to buy several of them. The store has n different matryoshkas. Any matryoshka is a figure of volume outi with an empty space inside of volume ini (of course
column8: outi>ini).You don\'t have much free space inside your bag
column9: but
column10: fortunately
column11: you know that matryoshkas can be nested one inside another. Formally
column12: let\'s call a set of matryoshkas nested if we can rearrange dolls in such a way
column13: that the first doll can be nested inside the second one
column14: the second doll \xe2\x80\x94 inside the third one and so on. Matryoshka i can be nested inside matryoshka j if outi\xe2\x89\xa4inj. So only the last doll will take space inside your bag.Let\'s call extra space of a nested set of dolls as a total volume of empty space inside this structure. Obviously
column15: it\'s equal to ini1+(ini2\xe2\x88\x92outi1)+(ini3\xe2\x88\x92outi2)+\xe2\x8b\xaf+(inik\xe2\x88\x92outik\xe2\x88\x921)
column16: where i1
column17: i2
column19: ik are the indices of the chosen dolls in the order they are nested in each other.Finally
column20: let\'s call a nested subset of the given sequence as big enough if there isn\'t any doll from the sequence that can be added to the nested subset without breaking its nested property.You want to buy many matryoshkas
column21: so you should choose a big enough nested subset to buy it. But you will be disappointed if too much space in your bag will be wasted
column22: so you want to choose a big enough subset so that its extra space is minimum possible among all big enough subsets. Now you wonder
column23: how many different nested subsets meet these conditions (they are big enough
column24: and there is no big enough subset such that its extra space is less than the extra space of the chosen subset). Two subsets are considered different if there exists at least one index i such that one of the subsets contains the i-th doll
column25: and another subset doesn\'t.Since the answer can be large

column2: implementation "There are n pillars aligned in a row and numbered from 1 to n.Initially each pillar contains exactly one disk. The i-th pillar contains a disk having radius ai.You can move these disks from one pillar to another. You can take a disk from pillar i and place it on top of pillar j if all these conditions are met:  there is no other pillar between pillars i and j. Formally
column3: it means that |i\xe2\x88\x92j|=1;  pillar i contains exactly one disk;  either pillar j contains no disks
column4: or the topmost disk on pillar j has radius strictly greater than the radius of the disk you move. When you place a disk on a pillar that already has some disks on it
column5: you put the new disk on top of previously placed disks
column6: so the new disk will be used to check the third condition if you try to place another disk on the same pillar.You may take any disk and place it on other pillar any number of times
column7: provided that every time you do it
column8: all three aforementioned conditions are met. Now you wonder
column9: is it possible to place all n disks on the same pillar simultaneously?" 1000

column3: math" "Alice and Bob have received three big piles of candies as a gift. Now they want to divide these candies as fair as possible. To do this
column4: Alice takes one pile of candies
column5: then Bob takes one of the other two piles. The last pile is split between Alice and Bob as they want: for example
column6: it is possible that Alice takes the whole pile
column7: and Bob gets nothing from it.After taking the candies from the piles
column8: if Alice has more candies than Bob

column2: a basketball court has been opened in SIS

column4: and he lined up them into two rows of the same size (there are exactly n people in each row). Students are numbered from 1 to n in each row in order from left to right.  Now Demid wants to choose a team to play basketball. He will choose players from left to right
column5: and the index of each chosen player (excluding the first one taken) will be strictly greater than the index of the previously chosen player. To avoid giving preference to one of the rows
column6: Demid chooses students in such a way that no consecutive chosen students belong to the same row. The first student can be chosen among all 2n students (there are no additional constraints)
column7: and a team can consist of any number of students. Demid thinks

column3: math" "Each evening after the dinner the SIS\'s students gather together to play the game of Sport Mafia. For the tournament
column4: Alya puts candies into the box
column5: which will serve as a prize for a winner. To do that
column6: she performs n actions. The first action performed is to put a single candy into the box. For each of the remaining moves she can choose from two options:  the first option
column7: in case the box contains at least one candy
column8: is to take exactly one candy out and eat it. This way the number of candies in the box decreased by 1;  the second option is to put candies in the box. In this case
column9: Alya will put 1 more candy
column10: than she put in the previous time. Thus
column11: if the box is empty
column12: then it can only use the second option.For example
column13: one possible sequence of Alya\'s actions look as follows:  put one candy into the box;  put two candies into the box;  eat one candy from the box;  eat one candy from the box;  put three candies into the box;  eat one candy from the box;  put four candies into the box;  eat one candy from the box;  put five candies into the box; This way she will perform 9 actions
column14: the number of candies at the end will be 11
column15: while Alya will eat 4 candies in total.You know the total number of actions n and the number of candies at the end k. You need to find the total number of sweets Alya ate. That is the number of moves of the first option. It\'s guaranteed
column16: that for the given n and k the answer always exists.Please note
column17: that during an action of the first option
column18: Alya takes out and eats exactly one candy." 1000

column8: there are k types of drink sets
column9: the j-th type contains two portions of the drink j. The available number of sets of each of the k types is infinite.You know that students will receive the minimum possible number of sets to give all students exactly one drink. Obviously

column5: and the digit denoting y\xe2\x80\xb2 is contained in the decimal representation of y. For example
column6: 2613 is a good fraction
column7: because 2613=21.You are given an integer number n. Please calculate the number of good fractions xy such that 1\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa4n and 1\xe2\x89\xa4y\xe2\x89\xa4n. The answer may be really large

column3: number theory
column4: probabilities
column5: two pointers" "Today Adilbek is taking his probability theory test. Unfortunately
column6: when Adilbek arrived at the university
column7: there had already been a long queue of students wanting to take the same test. Adilbek has estimated that he will be able to start the test only T seconds after coming. Fortunately
column8: Adilbek can spend time without revising any boring theorems or formulas. He has an app on this smartphone which contains n Japanese crosswords to solve. Adilbek has decided to solve them all one by one in the order they are listed in the app
column9: without skipping any crossword. For each crossword
column10: a number ti is given that represents the time it takes an average crossword expert to solve this crossword (the time is given in seconds).Adilbek is a true crossword expert
column11: but
column12: unfortunately
column13: he is sometimes unlucky in choosing the way to solve the crossword. So
column14: it takes him either ti seconds or ti+1 seconds to solve the i-th crossword
column15: equiprobably (with probability 12 he solves the crossword in exactly ti seconds
column16: and with probability 12 he has to spend an additional second to finish the crossword). All these events are independent.After T seconds pass (or after solving the last crossword
column17: if he manages to do it in less than T seconds)
column18: Adilbek closes the app (if he finishes some crossword at the same moment
column19: that crossword is considered solved; otherwise Adilbek does not finish solving the current crossword at all). He thinks it would be an interesting probability theory problem to calculate E \xe2\x80\x94 the expected number of crosswords he will be able to solve completely. Can you calculate it? Recall that the expected value of a discrete random variable is the probability-weighted average of all possible values \xe2\x80\x94 in this problem it means that the expected value of the number of solved crosswords can be calculated as E=n\xe2\x88\x91i=0ipi
column20: where pi is the probability that Adilbek will solve exactly i crosswords. We can represent E as rational fraction PQ with Q>0. To give the answer
column21: you should print P\xe2\x8b\x85Q\xe2\x88\x921mod(109+7)." 2400

column4: trees" "We have a magic tree: a rooted tree on n vertices. The vertices are numbered 1 through n. Vertex 1 is the root.The magic tree gives us magic fruit. The fruit only grows in vertices of the tree other than the root. Each vertex contains at most one piece of fruit.It is now day 0 and no fruit is ripe yet. Each fruit will only be ripe for a single day. For each fruit
column5: we are given the vertex vj where it grows
column6: the day dj on which it will be ripe
column7: and the amount wj of magic juice we can extract from it if we harvest it when it is ripe.The fruits have to be harvested by cutting some branches of the tree. On each day
column8: you may cut as many branches of the tree as you like. The parts of the tree you cut off will fall to the ground and you can collect all the ripe fruits they contain. All fruits that fall to the ground when they are not ripe are discarded and no magic juice is collected from them.Formally
column9: on each day
column10: you may erase some edges of the tree. Whenever you do so
column11: the tree will split into multiple connected components. You then erase all components that do not contain the root and you harvest all ripe fruits those components contained.Given is a description of the tree together with the locations
column12: ripening days and juiciness of all m fruits. Calculate the maximum total amount of magic juice we can harvest from the tree." -999

column3: math" "You have been hired to supervise the project of a new amusement park. The park will have a special gimmick: directed slides that can get customers from one attraction to another quickly and in an entertaining way.The park owner has given you the current project: a list of planned attractions and a list of slides that should be built between them. However
column4: him being a businessman
column5: he casually envisioned the impossible: among other things
column6: he projected a slide coming from the Haunted Castle to the Roller Coaster
column7: another from the Roller Coaster to the Drop Tower
column8: and a third from the Drop Tower to the Haunted Castle. As the slides can only go downhill
column9: it is evident why this is a problem. You don\'t have the luxury of ignoring the laws of physics when building the park
column10: so you have to request changes in the project. Maybe he would accept reversing the slide between the Drop Tower and the Haunted Castle?Formally:   The project is a list of attractions and a list of directed slides. Each slide starts at one attraction and ends at another attraction.  A proposal is obtained from the project by reversing the directions of some slides (possibly none or all of them).  A proposal is legal if there is a way to assign an elevation to each attraction in such a way that every slide goes downhill.  The cost of a proposal is the number of slides whose directions were reversed. For a given project
column11: find and report the sum of costs all legal proposals. Since this number may be large
column12: output it modulo 998

column4: meet-in-the-middle" "A cubeword is a special type of a crossword. When building a cubeword
column5: you start by choosing a positive integer a: the side length of the cube. Then
column6: you build a big cube consisting of a\xc3\x97a\xc3\x97a unit cubes. This big cube has 12 edges. Then
column7: you discard all unit cubes that do not touch the edges of the big cube. The figure below shows the object you will get for a=6.  Finally

column2: graphs "The leader of some very secretive organization has decided to invite all other members to a meeting. All members of the organization live in the same town which can be represented as n crossroads connected by m two-directional streets. The meeting will be held in the leader\'s house near the crossroad 1. There are k members of the organization invited to the meeting; i-th of them lives near the crossroad ai. All members of the organization receive the message about the meeting at the same moment and start moving to the location where the meeting is held. In the beginning of each minute each person is located at some crossroad. He or she can either wait a minute at this crossroad
column3: or spend a minute to walk from the current crossroad along some street to another crossroad (obviously
column4: it is possible to start walking along the street only if it begins or ends at the current crossroad). In the beginning of the first minute each person is at the crossroad where he or she lives. As soon as a person reaches the crossroad number 1
column5: he or she immediately comes to the leader\'s house and attends the meeting.Obviously
column6: the leader wants all other members of the organization to come up as early as possible. But
column7: since the organization is very secretive
column8: the leader does not want to attract much attention. Let\'s denote the discontent of the leader as follows  initially the discontent is 0;  whenever a person reaches the crossroad number 1
column9: the discontent of the leader increases by c\xe2\x8b\x85x
column10: where c is some fixed constant
column11: and x is the number of minutes it took the person to reach the crossroad number 1;  whenever x members of the organization walk along the same street at the same moment in the same direction
column12: dx2 is added to the discontent
column13: where d is some fixed constant. This is not cumulative: for example
column14: if two persons are walking along the same street in the same direction at the same moment
column15: then 4d is added to the discontent
column16: not 5d. Before sending a message about the meeting
column17: the leader can tell each member of the organization which path they should choose and where they should wait. Help the leader to establish a plan for every member of the organization so they all reach the crossroad 1
column18: and the discontent is minimized." 2500

column6: he doesn\'t answer and goes home immediately (this process is so fast that it\'s considered no time elapses). This student fails the exam.  if the student finds the ticket easy

column16: then while finding the answer for i2 (i2>i1) the student j student does not have to go home." 1700
